STBLKeyStringList.Text: A rabbit known to someone in the household has died. Farewell, {1.ObjectName}!
(From an Affectionate Moment with a Bird)

{1.ObjectName} just grew into a golden rooster! Wow their shine is so bright and golden!

They're sure to impress at a Finchwick Fair competition!

They'll also trade for more Simoleons than a normal rooster!

{1.ObjectName} has grown into a hen but this hen is different from the rest. They have an evil look in their eyes...

This chicken will occasionally lay valuable obsidian eggs! {1.ObjectName} should be treated kindly or they'll unleash a darker side. 

This rare chicken may be traded for better items!

{1.ObjectName} grew into a Golden Chicken! Wow, their shine is so bright and golden!

They're sure to impress at a Finchwick Fair competition! 

They'll also trade for more Simoleons than a normal chicken!
{1.ObjectName} is now a fully grown rooster. It'll crow in the morning, try to protect other chickens from foxes, and will try to breed with hens in the same coop to create Hatchable Eggs!

{1.ObjectName} has grown into a rooster but it has a dark presence. What horrors hide behind those glowing eyes?

This evil rooster will be able to scare off foxes but be careful when socializing with them!

This rare chicken may be traded for better items!
Wow! {1.ObjectName} has grown up into a Hen! {0.SimFirstName} can now harvest eggs that {1.ObjectName} has produced in the Coop. Make sure to check every morning to see if there are eggs to be found!

{0.SimFirstName} continued to be mean to an evil chicken even while it was unhappy! {M0.He}{F0.She} is really pushing {M0.his}{F0.her} luck right now. If {M0.he}{F0.she} does that one more time, this evil chicken is going to get angry! You won't like it when it's angry...
{0.SimFirstName} has really done it now! {M0.his}{F0.her} evil chicken can't take any more of {0.SimFirstName}'s meanness! ANGRY SPIRIT OF EVILNESS NAMED CHARLES HAS COME!
{0.SimFirstName}'s chick hatched on its own! Check them out on the coop to see if they are there!

A chick hatching from a dark, foreboding obsidian egg? What could go wrong? It may seem like an innocent little chick for now but {0.SimFirstName} should keep an eye on this little one. There's a darkness within...

A golden egg has hatched a special kind of chick. They may not look like it yet, but with time they'll manifest golden powers. {0.SimFirstName} should keep an eye on this little one as amazing things are bound to happen.
The egg that was incubated in the coop is ready to hatch! Have {0.SimFirstName} use Hatch Egg to see the hatching in progress!
{0.SimFirstName} helped a chick hatch from an egg! What a heartwarming moment!
{1.ObjectName} could not find their coop! They might run away if they can't find another one.
{1.ObjectName} is now under the effect of a Fishy Protein Treat! As a thank you, your chicken will lay an extra egg next time you harvest!
{1.ObjectName} is now under the effect of a Flirty Treat! This sweet treat will increase the chance of hens laying Hatchable Eggs.
{1.ObjectName} has now been transformed into a Golden Chicken! Become friends and ask them about their magic pulse powers!
{1.ObjectName} is now under the effects of a Healthy Treat! This increases a chicken's lifespan. Perfect for those that want to keep their chicken around for just a little bit longer.
{1.ObjectName} is now under the effects of a Friendly Treat! This will increase the relationship between the animal and the Sim. Finally! A chance to ask why they crossed the road!
{1.ObjectName} is now under the effects of a Fishy Protein Treat! As a thank you, the llama will produce one extra wool the next time you shear. Its so fluffy!

{1.ObjectName} is now under the effects of a Fishy Protein Treat! This increases the amount of milk produced by one for one milking. The cow liked that treat so much, they decided to give you a token of their appreciation!
{1.ObjectName} is now under the effects of a Healthy Treat! This increases the animal's lifespan. More time for pets and hugs!
{1.ObjectName} is now under the effects of a Healthy Treat! This increases the Llama's lifespan. The fluffiness will continue on!
{1.ObjectName} is now under the effects of a Friendly Treat! This will increase the relationship between the animal and the Sim. Sometimes you just need a little help making friends!
{1.ObjectName} is now under the effects of a Friendly Treat! This will increase the relationship between cows and Sims. The way to a Cow's heart is through a delicious treat!

(From the Death of a Rabbit Friend)
{0.SimFirstName} has traded {F0.her}{M0.his} chicken. A delivery of ingredients is coming in the mail soon!
(From Visiting the Isle of Volpe Ruins)
Extra jars have been placed in {0.SimFirstName}'s inventory!

Oh, everyone knows that it's customary around Finchwick to give a Finchwick Favor of cheese to the grocer. It's just a bit odd when they order the cheese from us only to give it back! Oh well, customs are customs, I suppose.
I know someone who orders ten milks a week. At that point, I'd just purchase my own cow!
I've got one customer who always swears there are mushrooms in the Bramblewood that only show up at night. Sounds strange to me.
Well, it's tradition to give the Grocery Delivery person Yorkshire Pudding around here. And no - I'm not making up that part about 'tradition' so that I'll get more free pudding. Preposterous.
The Crumplebottoms are always ordering crumpets. I wonder if that's where their name originated from?

Want to hear a ghost story? Have you heard of Lord Volpe, founder of Finchwick? Well, his first wife was Lady Volpe, a beauty who many thought a witch from the Bramblewood. Some say she spoke with foxes, others that she controlled the snails. What we know for certain is that she drowned in the River Bagley. If you go swimming in it nowadays without leaving a present for Sophie, she might pull you down. So best leave a little gift under Sophie the Snail lest you feel a tickle on your feet in the river, I say.

Do you know the mill in Old New Henford? Many years ago, there was an accident - that poor Algernon Watson - and they shut it down to make sure everything was safe before letting anyone back in. But the strangest thing! That very night, the mill started turning again, all on its own. They went by the next morning and the door was locked from the inside! They've never shut the mill down since. I'd reckon they're afraid to now.
When I took on the Pub, everyone started bringing me Cottage Pie. Apparently, it's the traditional Henford-on-Bagley Finchwick Favor. Not that I mind. Cottage Pie is delicious!

Are you looking to get spooked? Well, it's rumored that a pure obsidian egg can birth the incarnation of evil in its purest form. In time, a small, seemingly innocent chick will spring forth. But beware! For it is bathed in flames of terror and its destiny is one of fire. They say these very chickens conspire with the Grim Reaper. That's the rumor anyways. Probably just a tale to scare the children.

Want to hear my favorite Henford ghost story? It's the one about Maybell Watson. She was a local girl who used to ride her cute little bicycle around Old New Henford. It always had two fresh baskets of flowers, one on the front and one behind the seat. Maybell picked the flowers herself every morning down by the River Bagley. Well, one morning, she got up early before sunrise to go pick flowers like she did every other day. But on this day, she never came home and nobody ever saw her ever again. Some say she ran away, but others swear that if you look out over Olde Mill Lane in the early morning, you can see a bicycle with two flower baskets - one in the front and one in the back - riding itself along the dirt path, heading back up Olde Mill Hill, bringing the little Watson girl home.
Oh, and I foraged an extra mushroom that you can have. Try making a soup from it!
Well, if you want to make yourself useful for once, you could always fetch me some butter crumpets. I like mine fluffy... just like your brain! I jest, of course.
I have let certain men into my life in the past - Robert, Erik - but nothing good came of it. I spend my time with Agatha and my plants nowadays and that's enough for me.
Why can't I stand public displays of affection? How can anyone? Hmm — well, I suppose we have gotten close. You see, I was in love once. And? And it didn't end well.
I will admit that one thing I don't entirely hate is a well-constructed, high-quality cross-stitch. Now that's a proper use of a Sim's time.
Well, since I don't absolutely despise you, I'll let you in on a secret... I'm not actually from Finchwick. Have you ever heard of the Goths?

I love dressing up the animals. In fact, I could make an outfit for you if you've got the raw materials. I've known other locals to hand them out as 'thank yous' for helping out, too.\n\nI used to know a rooster named Sir Crowstoosoon. Wore a top hat all the time. Very proper. Got his feathers ruffled quite easily. Oh, I do miss that rooster. Not in the morning, mind you.

I get a lot of gifts from my creatures, given how close I am with them. I never get rainbow eggs, though. Not that I'm complaining. I love the gifts they give me. I just also happen to love rainbow eggs.
My first animal friend was a little bunny named Boo. It took a long time for me to befriend her, but once I did, we were inseparable. I'd visit her every day. We really had a special bond.

I used to know a fox named Mable. She was such a miscreant! Always chasing chickens and stealing eggs! Normal fox behavior, really, but she seemed to especially enjoy it. She once stole a golden egg from a man from Old New Henford just to watch him cry.
I once saw a Sim fight a rabbit and lose. As in, they really lost. Their life. You think rabbits are all cute and fuzzy - and they are - but one must respect them!
Did you ever hear the tragedy of Garden Gnome the Wise? I thought not. It's not a story the other villagers will tell you.
Agnes is my cousin and we've known each other since we were little girls. Honestly, she could stand to loosen up a little. Like me. I'm the fun one. Then again, I haven't gone through what she has.
You know, it was either run a garden cart or start my very own match-making service, but the gnomes really were taken by the flowers, so it was an obvious choice.
Few actually know about the Order of Gnomes. But I do! And it is real — but you didn't hear that from me.
Have you met my boyfriend of the week? He's a garden gnome. I do love garden gnomes. He won my heart with some jam crumpets - another of my favorites.
I get so much cheese from everyone. It's the traditional Finchwick Favor from the locals. I suppose there are worse problems than too much cheese.

It is perfectly safe to go swimming in River Bagley. Some people tend to shy away, because of a ghost story, but that's none of my business. If that kind of tale tickles your fancy, you should go talk to the Pub Owner.

Did you know that Old New Henford was originally called 'Little Henford,' but they tried to rename it 'New Henford' so that it would sound more posh? But nobody told the mapmakers and it disappeared from the maps entirely! It was a whole ado and in the end needed yet another new name and here we are today.

Olde Mill Lane in Old New Henford received its name after the mill was built here in Finchwick. People still call the mill in the village 'the New Mill' but by this point, it's older than almost anyone living here now.

Long ago, ancient druids ran a temple on the Isle of Volpe, deep in the Bramblewood. They shared a special connection with the foxes there. At least, that's what all the elders in the village have always told me.
Well, it is customary to gift the Finchwick Grocery Owner with cheese. It's expected around here. It's simply what one does!
Well, the Bramblewood's very own Creature Keeper clearly loves animals, but if there's one favor that they seem to always be seeking, it's a rainbow egg.
Yorkshire Pudding. Not just a scrumptious snack, but also the traditional favor for the Grocery Deliverer in Henford-on-Bagley.

What's the traditional favor to give the Finchwick Mayor? Why do you ask? Should I be expecting something? It's a medium-sized pumpkin, of course! Nothing too big and nothing too small, if you please.

Don't tell her I said anything, but there's one surefire way to get in Ms. Agnes Crumplebottom's good graces: the right Finchwick Favor. She's a sucker for high quality cross-stitches and butter crumpets.
Agatha is far easier to get along with than her cousin. Still, if you want to really make her day, she's always in the mood for jam crumpets, and everyone knows how much she loves her garden gnomes.
Dating back over a hundred years, it's a local Finchwick tradition to give the Pub Owner cottage pie. Why? I'm not sure, really. But we wouldn't want to break tradition, now, would we?
I haven't heard anything lately... at least, not that I'd share with you.
Apologies, but I'm quite busy and have no good gossip for you.
I'm not sure I'm of a mind to engage in such idle chitchat with you.
You want to hear a real secret? I find you distasteful! Ha.
Oh my dear, have you been getting into that biscuit jar again? You know those will go straight to your hips.
The NERVE of some people! Public displays of affection in MY town is not something I tolerate. You'd best behave yourself around here if you don't want to get on my bad side!
Why buy mushrooms and berries from the shops when you could be foraging in the Bramblewood and Old New Henford for free?
Chocoberries can be hard to find. That's common knowledge. What they don't know is that there are some growing on the Isle of Volpe in the Bramblewood. Shhhh. Don't tell anyone!
If you've got an excess of any berry but find yourself in need of another, I hear the Creature Keeper's the one to see for a helpful berry trade.

If you truly want to live your best life, there's a lot to learn from the creatures. Take the clever foxes we see around here. They're adaptable, perceptive, strategic, persistent — sometimes a touch too much. Be like the fox and you are bound to succeed.

You know what my Nan used to say? When times were hard, she'd say, 'This too shall pass.' And she was always right. She also said, 'It's a poor mother bird who has a poo in their own nest.' Which is also true, but probably not directly applicable advice right now.
Sims always come to me for life advice. You know what I tell them? Take it slow. Sometimes you try to do life on fast-forward and your needs get out of hand.

The critters love it when you spend time with them. I speak to them all the time. I tell them about my day. About what I ate. Dates I've gone on... that were awkward... and regretful — uh, where were we? The critters! Right. Yes, very good listeners.

The happier your animals are, the higher quality goods they'll produce. If you want nice eggs, keep happy chickens! Quality milk comes from well-socialized cows. And the fluffiest of wools grows on the cleanest of llamas.

Rabbits, birds, and foxes love to get gifts! Well, don't we all? If you want to get close to one of them, try figuring out what gifts it likes. Before you know it, it might be bringing you gifts from the woods, too.
No one enjoys being spit on, not really, and that includes foxes! If you've been having some fox troubles, having a llama in the right place to gob that bandit could be just the ticket.
Those foxes can be quite sly but I once saw a rooster take one on - beak primed, knives out, feathers flying - and give it what for, such that the fox had to admit defeat and slunk off in shame!
I've got a spot of extra food. Would you be a dear and accept it? Enjoy it for me, will you?

I've got some rabbits and birds helping out with my garden. The rabbits do their business and fertilize the plants, and the birds sing to the little sprouts. Plants are social creatures too, you know!
Why not get the children involved in gardening? Teach them about plants. Let them get their hands dirty. It's good for their minds.

It may go without saying, but if you want to grow an oversized crop, they need room to breathe. You can't just shove them into one of those little planters. Make sure they have their own gardening patch.

It's all rather simple. Pruning is important. Watering is essential. Fertilizer! Well, there are multiple types of fertilizer. Some make your plants grow quicker or healthier. Others improve quality. Some cause the plant to produce more fruit. It's important to use the right fertilizer to fit your needs. So, not so simple then.

Where do you get seeds? Well, obviously from the Crumplebottom Garden Stall in Finchwick. I suppose you could shop on the computer or order them through a grocery delivery service, but why buy from anywhere but the best? Perhaps I'm biased.

If you want your food to keep for a long time and you've got a stove, try canning it! You can can all sorts of things: pumpkins, lettuce, watermelons. And if you add a bit of sugar to your fruit, you get jam. Who doesn't love jam?
Cooking together can be good for your relationship. Think of it as a recipe for romance. Or companionship. Whatever you're looking for, really.
The better the ingredients you use, the better your recipe will turn out. My grocery stall has always got some fresh ingredients that'll be sure to enhance any recipe of yours.

What am I looking for when judging at the Finchwick Fair? Well, I'll always reward higher quality, rarity, size, and weight. And I do take into account how happy and clean the animals are. I'm quite chuffed by happy animals.
Happy, clean animals always place better at the Finchwick Fair. Sad animals simply dampen the mood.
Some people try to bribe me at the Finchwick Fair. To them, I say: don't try it unless you can make it worth my while! Ha! I'm clearly joking!

The well in the center of Finchwick used to be filled with water, but a certain elderly local hit someone so hard with her purse that they almost fell in! After that, the mayor had it drained and filled with flowers.

Some people say Lord Volpe, the founder of Finchwick, had a pet fox, while others insist that he had a pet snail. There are no definitive records either way, but I like to think that Sophie the Snail is proof positive that he was a snail man. Why else would there be a snail maze in the Bramblewood?

Before the bridge-building frenzy a few hundred years back - you'd think the village was called Bridgertown or something - you'd have to swim if you wanted to cross the River Bagley. Sims would always have their swimming clothes handy when doing errands around town!
Even though Finchwick has grown from the days when it was nothing more than a cemetery and an aubergine seller, it still feels like the sort of place where we're all willing to help each other out.
It's rumored young nobles on secret holiday used to abscond to the cottage at the top of Cordelia Falls in the Bramblewood. Oh, to have seen what they did when they thought no one was watching!

Finchwick was beset by pirates once! Princess Cordelia was visiting and it's rumored that she brought those scallywags as company. Then again, perhaps beset isn't quite the term to us, as they were all very polite while they were here. In fact, they're the ones who started the whole Finchwick Favor tradition!

One of the most romantic places in the Henford-on-Bagley area are the old Isle of Volpe ruins in the Bramblewood. Getting a kiss from your love when wrapped in their arms - why, it's like a scene from a movie. Don't we all want our happily ever after?

The Watson family used to own the entirety of the Old New Henford area, but over hundreds of years, they've been selling off plots one by one. I wouldn't be surprised if the half the headstones in the Finchwick cemetery were Watsons.

Did you know that the sunny flowers hanging in the lampposts around town all come from local gardens? Those in Finchwick are tended by any Sim with a spare moment, while others come from the homes of Henford-on-Bagley residents. In a way, their brightness is a reflection of the light we all shine on each other.

Finchwick was so named due to all the greenfinches in the area. Lord Volpe loved the way they sang to each other. We also have robins, great tits, willow tits, goldcrests, and blackcaps for any Sim looking to do a bit of birding.

Even though property values in the Bramblewood have risen quite steadily over the past few years, some who've lived in Henford-on-Bagley for quite some time have sworn they won't sell to those looking to turn the woods into the next hot vacation destination, or whatever it is they put on their brochures.

A few years back, someone renovated a historic barn in the Old New Henford area. I love seeing history preserved in special ways like that, a reminder that we don't have to leave our pasts behind to move forward.

The ruins on the hill outside of Finchwick used to be a lord's manor - a grand house that looked over all of Henford-on-Bagley. If you look closely, you can still see them all the way from Old New Henford.

Well, if you're looking for the best place to fish in the Henford-on-Bagley area, you'll want to stop by Old New Henford and visit the pond at the base of Olde Mill Hill. I once knew a Sim who claims to have caught a wolf eel there!

Simply because Old New Henford has been around for a while doesn't mean things don't change. Take the community garden, for example. An enterprising neighbor started it a few years back and the entire community has ensured that it's really taken off.
A little birdie just told me that {0.SimFirstName} has just unlocked a Bird cross-stitch pattern!
{0.SimFirstName} has just unlocked the Cat cross-stitch pattern! Simply the best!
Ring the cow bell! {0.SimFirstName} has just unlocked the Cow cross-stitch pattern!
A little birdie just told me that {0.SimFirstName} has just unlocked the Bird cross-stitch pattern!

{0.SimFirstName} has just unlocked the ability to craft the Llama Cross-stitch pattern! The llama pattern for Cross-stitch. The llama pattern chosen specially for Cross-stitch. The llama pattern. That pattern.
{0.SimFirstName} has just unlocked the Llamacorn cross-stitch pattern! This pattern will always hold a place in your heart!
What's up, {0.SimFirstName}? {0.SimFirstName} has just unlocked the Rabbit cross-stitch pattern!
{0.SimFirstName} has just unlocked an Advanced Pumpkin cross-stitch pattern! It wasn't even its final form!
{0.SimFirstName} has just unlocked the Agnes Crumplebottom cross-stitch pattern! The drama. The purse. The cross-stitch.
{0.SimFirstName} has just unlocked the Beef Wellington cross-stitch pattern! Looks good enough to eat!
{0.SimFirstName} has just unlocked the Chocolate Pie cross-stitch pattern! Me oh my!
{0.SimFirstName} has just unlocked the Cowplant cross-stitch pattern! What should we name it?
{0.SimFirstName} has just unlocked the Crumpets cross-stitch pattern! Looks tasty.
{0.SimFirstName} has just unlocked the Aubergine Cross-stitch pattern! What an abur-genius!
{0.SimFirstName} has just unlocked the Lettuce cross-stitch pattern! And that's just the tip of the iceberg!
{0.SimFirstName} has just unlocked the Pumpkin Pie cross-stitch pattern! Made from scratch!
{0.SimFirstName} has just unlocked the Watermelon cross-stitch pattern! So refreshing!
{0.SimFirstName} has just unlocked the Yorkshire Pudding cross-stitch pattern! Yum!
Into Fitness... Fitness Whole Pizza in My Mouth!
Live Everyday Like Its Taco Tuesday!
You Are More Than Who You Were!
When Opportunity Knocks, Open The Door!
As a reward for the help {0.SimFirstName} has provided in the past, a free item was added to the delivery:\n{2.String}
It's an additional complimentary item for {0.SimFirstName}!\n{2.String}

The founder of Finchwick, Lord Volpe, simply loved topiaries. He's said to have talked to them more than he did his own family! He bestowed a particularly splendid bovine topiary to Princess Cordelia upon her visit. We keep his memory alive today by decorating the town with them for each fair.

The very first Finchwick Fair? Well, it all started years ago when old Arley Watson wanted to show off his beloved llama, Chicken. No, not some sort of hybridized llama-chicken creature, but rather his llama that he had affectionately named Chicken! What a winner she was! Chicken was a very intelligent and friendly llama and Sims came from all around Henford-on-Bagley to meet her! It's no wonder that the fair became a regular tradition afterwards.
Did you know that years ago there was a chicken competition before there was ever an egg competition? I guess that means the chicken did come before the egg!
Did you hear that Chicken's cluck? It was pristine! A cluck like never heard before!
Do you think this Chicken is for sale? I really want to take it home with me! I feel like we have a bond.
This Chicken might win a consolation prize... maybe.
I heard someone say this Chicken pecked them! Maybe it's evil! Ha, evil Chickens.
Careful around this Chicken... I’m pretty sure I stepped in something.
Awww, look at this Cow. I don't think it'll win. I feel sort of bad for it.
This Cow looks very unamooosed. I don't think it'll win.
This Plant looks a little diseased...
Well... they tried. Someone grew this Plant. Was it grown with love? Probably not. But they tried... they tried.
Leaf this poor Plant alone! It wants to sit quietly in its inadequacy.
Are Eggs supposed to smell like this?
What a poor, sad little Egg. I think it's even cracked.
Did this Egg even come from a Chicken? It doesn't seem normal. No way it is winning.
I think this Crop is the wrong size... It's supposed to be giant right? Like Oversized?
Consider me fully unimpressed. Maybe they should have stuck to growing normal Crops.
This “Oversized” Crop seems a bit small... Maybe they should have gotten some help from the local Wildlife.
Yikes. I bet this llama has a great personality though?
Careful... I think this Llama just spit on someone!
This poor Llama! Who would subject it to being judged when its clearly not going to win...
I give this... baked construction a 3.13. It is not up to the standards of Pie.
Someone took perfectly good ingredients and stuffed them into this dough pouch, which I refuse to acknowledge as Pie.
I've seen cows who make more impressive Pies than this.
Whoa... I could smell this Milk before I even got close. That's gross.
Alright... I think this Milk has chunks in it, ew. No way it is going to win.
Why does this Milk look so watery? It is Milk, isn't it?
That Wool is so coarse I think I could golf on it... Ha! Anyone? Anyone? Alright, admittedly that joke was almost as bad as this competition entry!
This Wool doesn't look particularly strong, nor is its consistency very... consistent. I don't think it'll win.
This Wool is not wooly enough for the Wool club. Alright, there isn't a Wool club, but this is a competition, and I don't think it'll win.
Feathered and lethal! You just don't see it nowadays... Let's see how it pays off for the Chicken!
Wow, would you look at this Cow! This one could be the winner.
Mooove over other Cows, I think we have a competitor right here!
What a very nice Cow! Look how sweet it is. I bet it'll win for sure!
You can tell a lot of care and effort went into this Crop. I think it stands a chance at winning.
This entry looks really healthy. I wouldn't be surprised if it won.
Wow, this Plant looks scrumptious... I think it could win!
This Egg looks super smooth. Nice color and shape. I bet it could win!
Now that's what I call a 'good Egg.' I won't be surprised if it wins!
Wow! This is one of the biggest Oversized Crops I've ever seen!
I think this Oversized Crop will beat the record that was set last time!
This is one really grooving Llama. Look at it and its bad self!
Llama just say... I think this entry is going to win. Look how fluffy they are!
What a sweet, happy Llama. Look at its Llama face. Oh, I hope it wins!
I bet this Pie is going to grab a slice of victory! Look how fancy it is.
This entry will occu-pie my thoughts for the rest of the fair! How impressive.
Now this is a Pie that was made with love! What craftsmanship!
As a Milk Connoisseur - professional! I will personally verify that this is one quality glass of Milk.
Have you ever seen such rich, milky Milk? It is surely the milkiest!
This Milk is so... beautiful! It makes me want to moo. Is that a strange thing to say?
This Wool looks so soft! I just want to cuddle up with it.
Look at the crimp! The color! The strength of the fibers! The purity! I won't be surprised if that Wool wins the competition.
Wow! Surely this is the wooliest of the Wools. It must have come from quite the llama!

{1.SimFirstName} looks angry. It seems that all bets are off when it comes to the safety of {0.SimFirstName}'s chickens, rabbits, and fruits.

Meet the residents of Henford-on-Bagley who keep Finchwick running! Pitch in and become a part of our community by talking to the villagers and offering to help them with their various errands.
The Grocery Shop Owner runs the Grocery Shop stall in Finchwick's square.
Agatha's cousin who co-owns and helps run the Garden Shop stall in Finchwick's square.
Finchwick's Mayor is often spotted in Finchwick during the week and at the weekly, weekend Finchwick Fair, judging competition entries.
The Pub Owner runs the Pub in Henford-on-Bagley.
Agnes' cousin who co-owns and helps run the Garden Shop stall in Finchwick's square.
The Grocery Deliverer helps coordinate Henford-on-Bagley's local grocery delivery service and can often spotted in Finchwick, during the day.
The Creature Keeper spends most days wandering the Bramblewood, caring for the animals and plants.

{0.SimFirstName} has unlocked the ability to write a Simple Living Cookbook on the computer. This book can be read by others for maximum cooking skill gain.
Agnes seemed to think that cross-stitch was... adequate. But she's also asked {0.SimFirstName} to bring her yet another cross-stitch!

Agnes seems even less pleased with this cross-stitch, if that's possible! Disapproving of {0.SimFirstName}'s cross-stitching skills, she implies that she'll show {M0.him}{F0.her} a truly stunning cross-stitch herself if {0.SimFirstName} can manage the menial task of bringing her some wool.

Helpful, huh? Actions speak louder than words! Here -- take these pumpkin seeds and show me that you know the first thing about plants.

Then, take yourself over to that Grocery Owner, who I'm pretty sure I saw flirting the other day, and give them a good scolding!

Then, bring me some milk! I require milk!
Hello, mate! We would love for you to come visit us again in Henford-on-Bagley.
Have you met the locals in Henford-on-Bagley? It's a really close-knit community.
A lot of the villagers around Henford-on-Bagley have been needing help lately.
You seem the friendly sort! You know, if you want to help out, a few of the important local villagers are often in need a hand. Just walk up and Offer Help.
The Bagley Berry Fizz that {0.SimFirstName} drank has somehow attracted a fish, which hopped right into {M0.his}{F0.her} swimsuit! Odd and a bit uncomfortable, but a free fish is a free fish.

Have you ever had a dream? I dream every day of seeing the world, but my life has kept me here so far. For now, do you think I could live vicariously through your travels? Take a picture of someplace far-flung and spectacular and bring it to me!\n\nI do so wish I could make the Mayor understand. Do you know that I've never even had a chocolate pie? I just want to live!

You're a lifesaver! I need to collect a few grocery orders, so just write down what Sims want and then let me know. And if you don't mind, I'm feeling a bit peckish and could use a bite to eat. Could you bring me any single serving of food of your choice? Surprise me!\n\nOh, and here... Let me give you a rose to take to the lovely Creature Keeper who stays in the Bramblewood. I'm a bit nervous to deliver it myself! Would you mind bringing it to them and then telling me how it went?

You'll soon love our lovely village as much as I do! Why don't you wander over to Old New Henford and try to catch a fish in the lake, or visit some of the shopping stalls in Finchwick? Perhaps you'd be so daring as to do both!\n\nAh, and if I could ask a personal favor...would you kindly talk to the Grocery Deliverer? We're close, but I've always found it difficult to talk about where our dreams differ.

Things are all progressing according to Agatha's plan! With two single Sims having accepted a rose, it's time {0.SimFirstName} took a more direct role in enacting Agatha's machinations. Now to gather them together for the next step...
Hello dearie; it's Agatha giving you a ring. Thanks to your adept seed salesmanship, things are looking pretty good! Swing by for the next step in this business plan of ours.

Agatha here again... I see simoleons streaming into my account, so you must be up to something good! The sales business suits you my dear. Once you've put a bow on everything I asked of you, make your way over here so we can celebrate!

The Grocery Deliverer asked you to gift me that did they? What a thoughtful gesture... I took them under my wing since they were a young little thing, but I've sensed a reluctance lately when I talk to them. You've helped clear the air though; thank you. Won't you tell them that I would never stand in their way as they pursue their dreams? And I'll wallop 'em if they keep worrying over giving it to me straight!

That's delectable! Is this what I'm missing by never traveling beyond our town to learn new things? We even grow everything needed to make these right here in Henford-on-Bagley. If others won't do it, I'll take it upon myself to learn such recipes.
Mmm, tangy! That Bagley Berry Fizz is tickling the back of {0.SimFirstName}'s tongue. It certainly had the markings of a drink to remember...
What the funk? That Verdant and Funk is hitting all the right notes on {0.SimFirstName}'s palate! It's a drink that many would be thrilled to discover in a country pub.

If we want to put our pub on the map, we've got to highlight the local flavors of Henford-on-Bagley and give 'em all something they've never drank before! I've got some ideas brewing already, but I'll need some of the berries and mushrooms you'll find out in the Bramblewood.\n\nBring them to me and I'll mix up a Bagley Berry Fizz for you.

Thanks for the help! I'm supposed to go meet up with someone who has a package for me, but for the life of me, I can't remember who it is!\n\nCan you ask around until you find whoever has my package and then bring it back to me?

I was putting together some things to send out and I must have gotten a bit flustered because I managed to seal up this package and plum forgot who it's supposed to go to! Would you mind lugging it around for a bit and see if you can get it to the Sim that's waiting on it?

I haven't had a chance at a proper chinwag recently with some of the other locals, so I'm going to send you in my stead. Catch up on what's been happening around Finchwick and maybe even make a few friends! These Sims are the ones that keep the village running, after all.

Do you know who's always around and listening? The gnomes! Find a local gnome and ask them for some gossip, then let's have a sweet treat to celebrate afterwards.\n\nYou know what else would help? Find me some single Sims! I'm always looking for my next matchmaking project.

Love is in the air! Can you feel it? Well, perhaps it needs a slight nudge from yours truly - Henford-on-Bagley's own self-appointed matchmaker. Roses are known to help budding relationships blossom, and I've entrusted you with two of them. Offer them to two single Sims who would make the perfect pair, and see if they fall for each other.\n\nI also need your help selling some extra inventory Agnes and I have at our Garden Shop. It's simple really... You'll buy my overstocked seeds at an extraordinarily fair price, and then you'll speak to a number of other Sims about this exciting opportunity to sell surplus seeds. Get enough Sims on board, and we'll all be rolling in the green!

You want to show your worth? Let's see now.\n\nFirst, I need you to harvest that pumpkin you planted for me earlier. Next, I'd like to see what you can do with a needle! Cross-stitch something for me. And finally, a jar of mayonnaise would hit the spot. Bring me one!

Ah, yes, I knew I could count on you! Let's take a journey, you and I.\n\nI'll need you to get me some chocoberries and spicy mushrooms so I can make you a special mash. It may taste a bit odd, but I think you'll find it gives you real insight into some of the creatures around here. Enough talk! Let's do the mash - the mushroom mash!

My stomach is empty and my appetite is roaring. An Aubergine Parmesan would fill me right up! And as long as you're so graciously indulging me, Pumpkin Scones to finish my meal sounds scrumptious. Just a single serving of each please; I wouldn't want to be greedy after all.
Do you ever get cravings for chocolate? That's me, right now. But... I still want to eat healthy. I'll compromise and enjoy a fresh Chocoberry instead, assuming you're able to bring me one.

I could really go for a mushroom snack right now. They're nature's gift to my highly refined palate, and I wouldn't want to look a gift horse in the mouth, now would I? Now, please -- bring me some mushrooms!
I'm feeling a mite peckish, and some Blueberries seem like just the right pick-me-up. Nothing beats the freshly picked Blueberries that grow around town, but really -- any Blueberries will do!
I've got Raspberries on my mind. As I child, I would roam the countryside and pick wild Raspberries -- what a treat! Would you bring me some so I can relive a favorite childhood memory?

Oh, just thinking of a perfectly cooked Beef Wellington is making my mouth water. Are you skilled enough to prepare this culinary delight? I'd be ever so grateful were you to bring me one. And... I may be pushing my luck, but I love pairing a Beef Welly with a hunk of Cheese. So cheese, if you please?

I'll be the first to tell you, I love a good raspberry. It's my favorite fruit, don'tcha know? For some reason, admitting this to others results in peals of laughter. You're not going to laugh at me, are you? No? Good! Get moving then and get me a raspberry please.

When my sweet tooth starts aching, I slap my hand to scold myself and speak aloud, "Now {1.SimFirstName}... No sweet treats, not a single one!", and then I scarf down some berries to satisfy my cravings. I'm afraid my cravings are coming on again. Please, bring me a blueberry!

Everyone laughs when I say I need an aubergine. I don't understand... what's so funny about that? If you can just help an old lady out and give me an aubergine without any snickering, giggling, laughing, or snide comments, there's a nice reward in it for you.

Sometimes I daydream of Prince Charming, pumpkin carriages, and fairytales from my youth. But that's a silly flight of fancy, and I'm a sensible woman. Still... isn't it nice to fantasize? Bring me a pumpkin so that I might dream again, if only for a moment.

Is there a greater sensation than being out in the countryside with the sun shining down, and biting into a juicy watermelon? No, I think not. Please bring me a watermelon so that I might enjoy this simple pleasure yet again.
Lettuce wraps are the key to maintaining my fit figure. Bread? Be gone! To sustain this diet though, I need more lettuce. Bring me some so that I might plant even more of it in my garden.

Golden wool... It's the stuff of legends. But whispers on the wind have made their way to my ears, and I hear golden wool may be more than a myth. Might you acquire some for me? You'll be handsomely rewarded!

Ever since I heard murmurs of a milk as black as night, I knew I had to get my hands on this forbidden beverage. Please, I implore you... bring me a taste, and don't whisper a word of this exchange to anyone.
Do I dare ask for a golden egg? Yes, I do dare. It's unquestionably a delicacy, and today's the day I treat myself. Please, do what it takes to track one down and you'll be richly rewarded.

I trust you, but I'd be shunned by the other villagers if my secret got out. I don't like drinking tea! I tolerate that swill among friends just for the ability to swirl in some delicious milk and honey. That said, golden honey milk exists for Sims just like me. All the flavor, and none of that nasty tea! Bring me some, but keep quiet about it.

There's a simply fabulous wool that I absolutely must have. Dare I say, this llama's wool will be six times harder than any other I could ask you to procure? You've guessed it; it's wool from a rainbow llama that I seek!

The Finchwick Fair takes place every Saturday. It's one of my favorite local traditions, where everyone in Henford-on-Bagley comes together in the spirit of friendly competition. You've been awfully impressive as of late, what say you capitalize on your skills and submit an entry to a future festival for judging?

The first time I saw a green llama, I wondered if the poor dear was feeling a bit sickly. Turns out they're perfectly healthy though! And I must admit... I'm drawn to their gorgeous green wool. Won't you help bring me some?

I've been on a bit of a nutrition kick as of late, and enriched milk has become a staple of my diet. That said, it can be hard to come by in a little town like Henford-on-Bagley. You may be my last hope to source some, short of having it shipped from the city. Can you help?

I'm no spring chicken. Every day that passes is a day I grow older. I can swear I hear my bones creaking! Would you please be a {M0.pal}{F0.dear} and bring me some milk, to help me feel good and strong?

I've found blue eggs to have a subtly sweet taste that I've come to crave. The only problem? They're hard to come by; they don't exactly occur naturally in the wild! I've got excellent rewards to share with the first Sim to bring me another one of those succulent blue eggs.

From a young age we're told stories of green eggs and dream of someday eating one. Well now that I'm all grown up, I can choose to have green eggs whenever I please! Sadly, they're rare to come by. Could you help track one down for me?

I'll admit, I did a double take the first time I saw a blue llama. But they're incredible creatures, and I'm not one to judge! Bring me some of their beautiful blue wool and I'll make it worth your while.

Oranges and eggs... they're both wonderful for breakfast on their own, but people keep insisting they're even better when infused together. I haven't tried an Orange Egg that I've liked yet, but I'm always willing to give it another go. Could you bring me one?

White llama wool is a staple 'round these parts. I can never have enough to keep the shop's shelves stocked. What say you save me the hassle of finding a llama to shear, and I'll reward you kindly for your time.

I'm slightly embarrassed to admit this, so please keep what I'm about to say between us... I used to laugh at people who started craving pumpkin spice flavor in anything and everything, but now I can't get enough. Could you please bring me some Pumpkin Spice Milk?!

Call me traditional; a nice fluffy white Llama is all I need. But customers at the Grocery Shop are asking more and more about exotic orange llama wool. It's rare that we receive stock in that color, so it'd be wonderful if you could help source some.

Eggs are a true delight. Gulp three down raw, scramble another three on the stove, and I'm ready to power through my day. I'd certainly appreciate if you could bring me a half dozen so that I start tomorrow off on the right foot!
Customers have been asking for Beige Llama wool lately -- I suppose they want a smidge more color in their lives? Please, bring some so that the Grocery Shop will have more of it to sell.
I've been trying to convince myself to go vegetarian lately, but haven't taken the plunge. Would you be so kind as to bring me some mighty plant milk? Maybe it'll push me over the edge this time!

It drives me mad knowing there's tawdry gossip being exchanged, and let me tell you - my ears are burning! Most of the locals know my face, but perhaps they won't see you coming. Listen in on any gossipers you spot and clue me in on what's being said.

There's a Sim out there right now gifting delicious pies when we all least expect it! We'll be minding our own business and suddenly, BAM! There's a pie. It's disconcerting and delicious, and I need you to ferret out who it may be.\n\nAsk around, though be aware that confessing to this sort of thing isn't something someone just does! While I trust our villagers to not lie to your face, you may need to get in their good graces before they come clean.

Oh wonderful; thank you for your continued help. I've been busy as a bee, and my backlog of tasks to tend to is getting unbearably long! But with you here to share the load, no doubt it'll be a productive day.

Have I mentioned that I'm an ornithologist hobbyist? Oh, silly me... I suppose that comes off a bit snooty. Really, I just enjoy watching birds, and would love to have a fellow bird watcher to banter with. What's that they, say... "birds of a feather", and all that good stuff? Go find some birds to watch; maybe you'll enjoy it!

Chitter chatter, pitter patter, the bunnies run to-and-fro... Oh, my heart just swells when I think about the sweet conversations I've had with my rabbit friends, but it can be so difficult getting them to slow down and say hello! I promise it's worth the effort though... Just scrunch your face up and try your best at wiggling your nose, and you'll be communicating with these sweet buns in no time.

Can you outfox a fox? I'm not trying to be clever, I'm literally asking you to to go watch the local fox population! Increased fox sightings have been reported across Henford-on-Bagley, and I want you to observe them and ensure they're still getting on just fine.

What does the fox say? Wait, don't answer. That's a rhetorical question, because you haven't gone and talked to one yet. Come {M0.man}{F0.woman}; am I not making myself clear? Run along and talk to a fox! I must know what's on our woodland's friend's minds.

Hip hop, to the hippity hop, hip hip hop and they don't stop! Sorry -- please don't mind me, my mind turns to mush when I think about just. how. cute. those adorable little rabbits are! Go watch some rabbits from afar; you'll soon love them and wish to help care for them just as much as I do!

Oh, what's this? A fresh face? Always lovely to see someone new around the village. Can you be a dear and help me out with some things?

I've heard that there's some juicy gossip around but I've only got two ears. Can you find a gnome who knows some things, and some Sims who don't know what they're missing?

You'll help, won't you? Oh, of course you will, I can see it in your eyes!

Could the message from the gnomes be any clearer? Love is in the air! Or at least it will be once I sprinkle a little of my matchmaking magic. Perk up my dear, we're in this together now. Come see me again when you're ready for our next undertaking.
Rewards: A decorative gnome and oversized crop seeds.

Ooh, I knew I could count on you. You're just what this village needs - a pair of fresh ears for catching all that gossip! Now, I've got an urge to do some meddling... well, actually -- I prefer to think of it as matchmaking! And my dear cousin Agnes has left me all this stuff to sell, which sounds frightfully dreary to do on my own.\n\nThink you can help me on both counts?

Oh dearie what a day! Those two youngin's will be falling for each other any minute now. I know how to pick 'em. Up 'n down the River Bagley, Ole' Agatha has spotted every future pair of lovebirds before even Cupid himself knew what was coming. But that's neither here nor there... Thanks to you my business is booming, and I've got some Simoleons burning a hole in my pocket. Ta ta!
Rewards: A decorative gnome, a flirty potion, and a fertilizer which greatly increases the quality of crops.

What's this? Who are you? What do you want from me?

Oh, you want to help?! We'll see about that. I've been meaning to get a pumpkin and that pub's been a hotspot of disgustingly flirty Sims! Show me you know the first thing about growing things and berating folks and maybe I'll have more for you to do.

Ugh, and I could use a drink!
Hrmm... A satisfactory outcome; yes. Turns out you weren't a complete waste of my time! I'm sure I can put your idle hands to good use in the future, so do come see me again.
Rewards: A special fertilizer that increases the speed of plant growth, and a cross-stitch pattern.

Well, maybe you aren't so useless after all. If you really want to prove yourself, I've got some even bigger errands for you to do.\n\nAnd don't say I didn't warn you! I expect these will take you more time than just a shake of a llama's tail, if you catch my meaning.

You're still standing there? That was all I needed; you can leave now! Well... I suppose you can tag along. If you enjoy my company so much, I'm sure there's more errands I can scrape together that you may tend to.
Rewards: A unique cross-stitch, a Cowplant Berry, and fertilizer to increase the size/weight of oversized crops.

Do you like mushrooms? I love them! There are some really good ones out in these woods and I could use some help foraging them.\n\nYou seem like a lover of the natural world that surrounds us. Why don't you stick around and I can show you some of what I know?
My friend! I think you've come to see the forest through the trees. Happy trails, until our paths cross again...
Rewards: An assortment of Produce, Flowers, Mushrooms, Fertilizer, and a piece of Animal Clothing.

You ever have one of those days where you've got too much to do and not enough time to do it?\n\nI need some ingredients for my next meal, but I'm not sure when I'll have any spare time. Would you be able to help me out?

Can you hear my stomach from all the way over there? I don't mean to intrude but you seem like quite the Sim-about-town. Could you find some time to get me something to munch on before my belly causes even more commotion?
I am! Who's going to help? You are!\n\nSorry, don't mean to be too silly, but I would like a bit of help if you'd be so kind as to fetch me a bite to eat or something to snack on?

Oh yummers; that looks divine! Please accept some small tokens of my appreciation. They'll come in handy the next time you prepare a meal. Now if you'll excuse me, I've got some tasty food to tuck into.
Rewards: An assortment of ingredients, Fertilizer, and (if you're lucky) a freshly prepared Meal.
How's that garden of yours going? You do have a garden... right? I'm always on the lookout for some new plants! So it's settled then, you're going to help me?
There's no pleasure like that of ushering some small bud into bloom.\n\nShow me that we're two peas in a pod by growing something for me, can you?

Some people think that plants just seed and sprout all on their own, but not us. We know better, don't we?\n\nThere is quite a bit of important preparation that goes into keeping our plants happy. I'd love a particular plant from you if you've got the inclination.
Well well, the {M0.boy's}{F0.girl's} got a bit of a green thumb about {M0.him}{F0.her}! Not too shabby.
Rewards: Oversized crop seeds, fertilizer, and a chance to receive a berry or mushroom to plant.

Have you been outside this village? I was born here and have been looking for a chance to explore beyond the borders of the woods and fences that seem to have defined my whole life.\n\nWould you mind helping to show me a bit of what I might be missing, or maybe even talking to the Mayor about my dreams?

Knowing I have the Mayor's support to experience what lies beyond Henford-on-Bagley makes my idle daydreams not seem quite so distant. I'm going to keep the photo you shared, and perhaps one day I'll see it with my own eyes. But for now... well, I think I'm going to go tuck into another chocolate pie!
Rewards: Postcards, an Animal Treat, an Upgrade Part for an Animal Shed, and a Coupon for a free Grocery Delivery.

It's lovely to see a new face around these parts, but I'm just too busy right now to make a proper introduction of myself. If you've the time and mind to be a help, would you be a dear and grab some of those grocery orders?\n\nOh, and I've forgotten to eat again! Not to mention that bouquet I was going to make for my friend!
Finding love in a small town is always a bit tricky. Well you played your part, and for that I thank you. It's back to the shop for me while I plan my next move.
Rewards: An assortment of eggs, milk, flour, cheese, sugar, and an animal treat.

I'm starting to recognize you as a regular. By now, I'm sure you know your way around the plants and animals we have around here. Do you know what I'd love to see?\n\nI want you to show off everything you've learned! Do you think you're up for it?

You seem like you've been doing quite well for yourself! I do believe that with the way you handle yourself around the animals, you've made quite a name for yourself here in Henford-on-Bagley.\n\nWe could always use a bit of a local hero around these parts. I've got an errand that'll test your expertise if you're game!
Someone was saying that you were the Sim to see if I wanted a real animal whisperer around these parts.\n\nCan you show me what you're able to do? I'd love to see it.
I knew you'd come through; I had faith in you from the very start! What a valued member of our little neck of the woods you've proven to be.
Rewards: Oversized crop seeds, fertilizer, Animal Shed upgrade parts, and a chance to receive animal clothing.

I'm not sure if you've got any creatures of your own, but I've been looking to get my hands on some fresh ingredients.\n\nCould you bring some to me and save me a bit of time going back and forth on my own?

I'd love to be spending my days among the furry creatures so many of our villagers seem to care for around here, but I've got groceries to tend to.\n\nIf you'd kindly grab what I need from one of those lovable beasts, I'd appreciate it.
I need to restock the grocery shelves a bit and I hear that you've got a bit of an animal connection.\n\nWould you mind tracking down something for me?

I appreciate the value of a full day's work. The Grocery Shop doesn't run itself after all. Believe me when I say how much I appreciate the effort you must have undertaken to gather the animal byproducts that keep this stall's shelves stocked. Until our paths cross again then!
Rewards: An Animal Treat, an Upgrade Part for an Animal Shed, a chance at new Treat recipes and Animal Clothing, and a Grocery Delivery Coupon.

I already know you'll love it here, but in case you need any convincing, I've arranged a little self-guided local tour!\n\nTake up these few - and fun, if I say so - errands and I'll make sure you get a small bundle of rewards at the end!

Well then, I believe you've had a proper look at the local landscape. If you're wanting even more to do, might I suggest popping out to the Bramblewood? It's a bit of a trek, but the scenery is straight out of a fairytale. Look for the Creature Keeper who lives out that way, they may have some errands to keep you busy.\n\nOh and don't forget to attend the Finchwick Fair on Saturdays; there's always various friendly competitions taking place where you can best your neighbors. It's judged by yours truly - so stay on my good side!
Rewards: An assortment of berries, llama wool, and animal treats.

My pub's been rather successful but I'm always looking for the next big thing. I think I have a lead on a new and exciting drink we could offer here - and only here!\n\nBut running the pub keeps me busy and I could use a little help. What do you think? Would you like to help make some mixology magic happen?
Wonderful choice! Between you and I, that was the option I hoped you'd pick. This new signature drink is sure to put our town's pub on the map!
Rewards: A new drink recipe, cooking ingredients, and a freshly prepared meal.

There's gossip out there and I don't know what it is! I mean, I don't need to know it all but I really want to.\n\nCan you go and figure out what the latest is? I'm too busy to go myself but I really must know!

I'd love to pretend that something grand and mysterious is happening, but I'll be honest - I think there's just some tomfoolery afoot.\n\nNow I don't have the patience right now to find out exactly what it is, but if you can be my eyes and ears, I'll make it worth your while!
There are secrets on the breeze, my friend, and I need a Sim with a nose for gossip and a penchant for helping to sniff them out for me.\n\nIs that you? I think that may be you.
In a town where there are no strangers, you'll find that everyone still has their secrets. You've cast light on something particularly intriguing today though, and for that I thank you.
Rewards: A Grocery Delivery Coupon, a Flower, a Cross-stitch Pattern, and an Uncommon flavor of Milk.
I've been meaning to pay a visit to some of my friends around the village, but I'm awfully busy. Would you mind taking a stroll and seeing how everyone's doing?
Do you know what makes for a pleasant village? Good neighbors! I'm sure you'd love to help me sort some neighborly duties out while meeting some of the lovely folks we have around here.
I haven't had a chance to make the rounds recently. Would you mind going to say hello to some of the villagers while helping me with an errand?
One of the best things about living in Henford-on-Bagley is the sense of community everyone here helps foster. Thanks for checking in with a few of the locals, and don't be a stranger!
Rewards: A local Meal, some Berries, an Upgrade Part, and a chance of receiving a Cross-stitch Pattern.

There's something about the woods, about being surrounded by the natural world, and letting your senses go. I want to share that with you.\n\nDo you trust me? I'm going to ask something of you, but it's really going to be for your own good. Are you ready?
Some say you make your best friends at school, but I say true friendships are born in the forest.\n\nCare to help me out and see what I mean?
The woods are alive with the sound of creatures. With mushrooms they eat, for a thousand years!\n\nOh, sorry, I thought I was alone. Err...would you mind helping me with some Bramblewood errands?

We've been through a lot, you and I. I hope I've opened your eyes to the generous bounty mother nature provides, and how it's our responsibility to tend to the innocent critters of the countryside. Continue visiting me in the future and together we'll ensure these lands remain pristine for the next generation.
Rewards: As assortment of harvestables, fruits, and flowers, a Mysterious Mushroom, and a piece of animal clothing.

There's a lot of nature out there and try as I might, I can't keep an eye on all of it. I wouldn't mind having a second set of hands from time to time.\n\nSomething between a friend and a business partner, you know? Think that could be you?
I haven't made a survey of my creature friends in a bit and it'd be lovely if someone could check in on a few of them and let me know how they're doing.
Those critters out there need our care! If we look after them, they'll keep this world a good place for us all to inhabit.\n\nIt's an important errand - are you the one to do it?

It fills me with joy to see you bonding with the local wildlife, and giving them attention while I was busy elsewhere. Please, enjoy this assortment of odds and ends I scraped together to show my appreciation!
Rewards: An assortment of fruit, wool, and a piece of animal clothing.
I see plants and animals that could use some tender loving care. What do I do?

This simple yet fine door frame was hand-crafted in Doorshire. Recently it became embroiled in a town scandal when a rich, aristocratic landowning door named Mr. Doorcy took a liking to this particular doorframe. Mr. Doorcy proposed, despite this doorframe's lack of a door dowry (Door-y?) and low social status. Will this doorframe and Mr. Doorcy ever be wed? Regardless, it looks great in any room.
This tall column adorned with a fantastic floral design is just the support your home needs. It’s also over two Sims tall, if that’s the way you measure things.

A Sim in your household is already working on this errand.
A fox is stalking around your home! Hide your hens, hide your eggs!

Humpty Dumpty sat on a fence Humpty Dumpty was in suspense And all the king's horses and all the kings men Couldn't cure Humpty of his crippling anxiety around walls. This fence has proved to be a good substitute for poor Humpty though, and it can be a lovely partition for your home as well! Just please, refrain from sitting on it.

Humpty had a high price to pay For being so playful day after day And the poor wall got all the blame For cracking poor Humpty's delicate frame Is there a moral in this tale at all? If you're an egg, don't sit on a wall.

X marks the spot! Rumor has it that pirates built this fence after deciding to abandon their old ways and settle down in the country. You might say they traded in fencing with swords for plain old fencing.
Aw a cute little chick. Will they grow to be a good hen?
A hen can lay eggs while they are in a coop. If you have a hen and a rooster, the hen might lay Hatchable Eggs.
Aw! This little chick is gonna grow to be a radical rooster!
A rooster for your coop is a good idea if you want them to breed and create Hatchable Eggs. Also good to protect the coop from predators and act as nature's alarm clock!
This bird is part of a flock of feathered friends.
Your chicken is ready for the countryside lifestyle with this stylish top piece.
Balderdash! Transform chickens into birds of culture with this fancy high-class outfit.
Too small for a Sim, too large for a bee. Just right for a chicken!
It's a HAT. On a CHICKEN. And a SCARF. OMG.
Your chicken may not understand polka dot style, but they will in time, because it is a timeless classic.
It's not a turtleneck because this sweater is for a chicken, not a turtle.
This top hat is exquisite and elegant. Give your chicken the posh lifestyle it always dreamed about.
Your cow will be over the mooooooon about wearing this cap and top combo.
Live. Love. Moo. Show that your cow is hardcore about living the cottagecore life.
Just the right amount of cowbell for a single cow. No more!
As a professor of art history, Professor Moos'alot regrets many things, but this outfit is not one of them.
Give your cow a cozy look with this bright, cheery sweater and an adorable pom-pom hat.
My, what big ears are peeking out from that bonnet!
That little mask isn't going to hide the identity of the fox who keeps swiping all your stuff!
Robber's Gear in Shades of Grey
A dashing outfit for foxes who steal from Sims for the benefit of forest creatures, namely themselves.
Can llamas fly? Your llama might believe it can while wearing this aviator hat and scarf!
Give your llama a look that says this llama is all about cultivating an aesthetic.
No one has ever seen a real llamacorn, but you can get your llama close with this llamacorn costume.
Improve your llama's geek chic-appeal with this colorful neckwarmer with glasses.
There's nothing wrong with throwing a colorful blanket on your llama to brighten the day.
Give your rabbit that bunny-eared look with this bow tie.
A simple but stylish dress that a rabbit will no doubt love. It even has pockets!
A sophisticated look for rabbits that's comfortable to hop around in.
A sweater vest can soothe any bad hare day.
Cows must be kept in an Animal Shed. Cows produce milk, which can be changed by feeding them Animal Treats. Make sure to give your Cow some Attention, Food, and keep them clean!
Apple and Blueberry Jam together make the perfect combo for a delicious snack. Animals that eat this treat will produce blue eggs, enriched milk, and blue wool.

This chocolatey treat is made from special chocoberries and custard that your animal will love. This treat will make your livestock animal's next harvest a Chocolate egg, Chocolate Milk, or Brown Wool.
This treat may be seem a little fishy, but trust me! Livestock animals will love this treat so much, they'll produce one extra milk, egg, or wool next time you collect.

This treat is almost as sweet as your animal friend! Made from strawberry jam and a pinch of sugar, this treat increases the chances of chickens laying Hatchable Eggs, makes Strawberry Milk, and Pink Wool

Who doesn't love a little gold? Add Cowberry Jam or Honey to a Golden Egg and you get a Golden Treat for your animal. Animals that eat this produce Golden Honey Milk and Gold Wool. This treat also turns chickens into golden chickens! So shiny!
Looking to stay with your sweet animal friend a little longer? Add lettuce to any fruit or veggie to create this treat that will increase a livestock animal's lifespan.
Having trouble making friends with your livestock? This treat may be plain, but it packs a friendly punch. This treat increases the relationship with you and your animal friend.

Cowberry Jam and Obsidian Eggs make up this dark treat. Animals that eat this produce Obsidian Milk and Black Wool. Chickens however... Beware! This treat taps into the darkest feelings of your chicken and transforms them into something new. Something... evil.
It's never too soon for some pumpkin spice! Pumpkin and sugar together make up this delicious snack. Animals that eat this treat produce orange eggs, pumpkin spice milk, and orange wool.

Made from special rainbow eggs, this majestic treat brings a new world of color to your animals. Animals that eat this will produce Rainbow Eggs, Rainbow Wool, and Rainbow Milk. This treat is so strong, even the Cows change color!
There's no party like an animal party! Made from mushrooms and any berry, this treat will increase your livestock animal's social motive.
Add any veggie to a spicy mushroom and you got yourself a Spicy Treat! Animals that eat this will produce obsidian eggs, fire milk, and red wool.

Lettuce, Aubergine and a little love make up this Veggie Treat. Animals that eat this will produce Green Eggs, Green Wool, and a very special Mighty Plant Milk (perfect for our lactose intolerant friends).
Piles of animal treats for chickens to eat.
Piles of chicken feed for chickens to eat.

Sims can use an Animal Shed on their lot to buy* their very own cow or llama! Though mostly easygoing, cows and llamas are rather intense homebodies – that means one animal per shed, that the animal sticks close to at all times. Sims who tend to the feeding and cleanliness of these animals, and their sheds, will be rewarded in no time\n\n*Cow/llama sold separately. Shed weather vane is decorative. Do not attempt to predict natural (or unnatural) events using weather vane.

Just a wild rabbit doing rabbit things. This rabbit is not a pet, but it might enjoy getting pet by a trusted Sim. Befriended rabbits can help Sims with gardening by enriching the soil around Oversized Crops and by eating weeds. Rabbits love to give and receive gifts, but they can be a bit picky!

You don’t have be named Anne to enjoy this grand gable. It's like a mini roof for your window or door! Great for anyone wanting to keep the rain off your front porch, or for people who like putting hat-like items on things.

If your thatched awnings start thinning up top, that's when it's time to call the Hay Club. Don't try to just comb over the existing straw to fill in the gaps. The Hay Club offers thick, full thatch options for any awning that could use a bit of a make over. Therre's no shame in wanting your awnings to look bang-on!
Classic Bangs Roof Toupee Awning - By the Hay Club
This simple paper bag is extremely durable and deceptively deep, capable of holding all manner of foodstuffs and other wares.

This lovely flower box balcony was modeled after the one used during the last Henford-On-Bagley Shakespeare in the Park performance of Romeo and Juliet. Many people questioned the casting of Juliet, but Mrs. Crumplebottom did put on quite the dramatic performance, much of which was done from this very balcony! Ah, the magic of community theater.

When you go out tubbing with friends, you don’t want to be rolling out in no nicked up bog. Ya wanna take Sir Dancealot with ya. Sure it’s got 4 left claw feet but when it’s really gotta be poppin’, there’s nothin’ else like it on the dance floor. I mean, who do ya think invented Tub Step, anyway? Yeah. This guy.
The Sir Dancealot Tub - by Douggie Industries

This lovely bed is featured at the Spring Sparrow Inn, which is under new management. A good thing too since the previous innkeeper's black pudding was so salty it would make the ocean blush. At least the beds were always comfortable though!

A flock of wild birds fluttered through the forest to make this their home. They are amenable to receiving gifts and may offer gifts in return. They are happy to devour plant-eating insects or sing to Oversized Crops as a favor to their friends. They are majestic little creatures. (But really hard to tell apart as individuals!)
Unlock by befriending a Flock of Wild Birds\n\nFlocks of birds can be found living inside dead trees in Henford-on-Bagley in The Bramblewood and Old New Henford
Unlocked by befriending a Flock of Wild Birds
This book can be used to gain tremendous amounts of cooking skill!

Don’t you want somebunny to love… your books, that is? Well, The Bunny Book Sandwich is you’re bestsellers bestie. The 2 bunnies hug your books in a way that only you would… if you were a book bunny. So, before you snuggle up with a good book, let your books snuggle up in The Bunny Book Sandwich. They’ll keep your books organized and feeling loved. Trust me, it’s way better than using The Caring Herring.
Bunny Book Sandwich BookEnds - by Hare Care Products Inc.
What could be inside this Mayor's Complimentary Weekly Mystery Jam Club reward box?
A leaf wrapped gift, shared between animals and their friends.
A leaf wrapped gift, shared between animals and their friends.
A leaf wrapped gift, shared between animals and their friends.

Another outstanding piece by Jack Whittler - master whittler of Old New Henford and all the neighboring villages. According to county records, Jack whittled these cabinets in a record time of one hour and twenty-two minutes. For his prize, Jack took home one of the village's finest hen whom he named Jenkins, after his whittling competition rival.

Use the coop to buy and care for hens, roosters, and chicks! Hint: you can build a fence around your coop to keep chickens from getting too far away. Must have at least one rooster and one hen in this coop to breed and create hatchable eggs!

Made of beautiful brick and adorned with two chimney pots, this chimney will attract singing chimney sweeps and Father Winters alike. As attractive as it may be, make sure no one actually attempts to slide down this chimney since your home insurance probably won't cover any damages caused by chimney-related antics or chimney enthusiasm.
Turn of the Century Brick Chimney

This here's the finest chimney in all of Old New Henford! Originally constructed during the early 1900s when being a chimney sweep was a noble profession which included elaborately choreographed song and dance numbers.

What time is it when the big hand is on the 12 and the little hand is on the 8? I literally can’t say since only time will tell. And your old junker clock ain’t talking because the hands are frozen in time and it’s bell tolls for no one. Perhaps what it’s really time for is a new clock. Well, the hands & bell on the Perfect Timing Clock function in the same non-functional way but in a much more charming, country cottage kinda way. I guess you’d say that this timepiece is simply, well, timeless.
Perfect Timing Wall Clock - by TimeZup
A festive and cozy little stand to roost fair competition entries upon.

These wee pieces of wood that stick out from the wall to help carry structural weight are often called "corbels" but in this part of the world, they're called braggers. Maybe because in Henford-On-Bagley, we're proud of everything our braggers can accomplish. They help hold up entire buildings which is more than I've done today, so good on 'em.
A box of something good, purchased from the garden shop.
A box of something good, purchased from the grocery shop.

This hand-whittled well-loved kitchen island will be there for you every time you need to roll dough, chop vegetables, sneak frosting off the side of a cake, or rest your tea cup. Sure, it's sustained some wear and tear over the years, but you know what they say: never trust any food that comes out of a pristine kitchen.

The entire line of Whittler's Pride kitchen furniture came to be after a century old whittling competition held in Old New Henford over a century ago between Oliver Jenkins and Jack Whittler. Of course, Jack Whittler won, teaching everyone that sometimes you really can judge a book by its cover... or in this case by its last name.\nEveryone later learned that Jack Whittler had earned his last name in a previous whittling competition, which is how folk used to get last names back in those days. Jack went on to whittle plenty of other notable items around Henford-on-Bagley, but these kitchen counters were some of his finest work.
Large cross-stitch display for the wall.
Medium cross-stitch display for the wall.
Small cross-stitch display for the wall.
A large hoop used for cross-stitching.
A medium size hoop for cross-stitching.
A small hoop used for cross-stitching.

The world of embroidery is at your fingertips with the Make it Sew Cross-stitching Kit. Inside you'll find bobbins, needles, and all the skeins of floss you need. Llama wool can be used for those looking to add an extra handcrafted touch. Take a seat and make it sew!

The Roman curtain was invented during the construction of the Roman Colosseum, one of the 7 Wonders of the world. These Roman curtains right here might be the 8th Wonder. Just look at that sleek design and sumptuous fabric!

Finchwick has all the quaint charms of a cozy village - but with that comes gossip! If you don't care to have your personal business strewn about the town like an old fish 'n chips wrapper, get yourself one of these doors. You know what they say: the heavier the door, gossip no more!

It never hurts to have a solid door! This one takes security one step further with a no-nonsense metal lock to help keep out any townies you might not be too excited about having over for tea and biscuits.
They say the eyes are the windows to the soul, but for a door, windows are the windows to the other side of the door. That's deep. Think about it. Or don't, and just admire your new door!

This door's got everything you could ever want in a quintessential cottage door: gorgeous wood paneling, a weighty knocker, ergonomic handle, and a mail slot. But even doors get lonely sometimes, so it's looking for a good home where it can be appreciated. Are you going to sing it bedtime songs at night? Listen to its hopes and dreams? Maybe smoke it a kipper for breakfast in the mornings? No? Drat. We almost had you smoking fish to feed to a door.
Celebrate the winter solstice any time of year with this whimsical woodsy door! Complete with a mossy pine wreath and a butterfly to remind you that even in the coldest winter, spring is on the way.
Dogs "knock" by barking, cats knock by meowing, birds tweet...but how does the fox knock? Why, with this lovely knocker of course. Anything else would make even less sense than gibberish.

Mirror mirror on the dresser
Tell me I'm the greatest treasure
Show me if my hair looks neat
Or if there's something in my teeth.
Milk can be used in recipes or drank straight from the bottle.
How can something be so refreshing and spicy at the same time?
This milk from a Midnight Treat sparks something dark and angry inside of a Sim.
Tipping that cow some simoleons really paid off.
Milk and Chocolate? The perfect mix!
Pure decadence. A touch of gold makes this milk a precious commodity.
It's always Pumpkin Spice Milk season!
Flirtatiously fruity, this milk goes perfect with a sweet dessert after a lovely dinner date.
Why are there so many milks that are rainbow? It's delicious, colorful, and will put any Sim in a playful mood!
A golden egg can only be laid by the golden chicken. Wow, look how it shines!
An egg made of chocolate? Is this some kind of dream?
They say Charles hatched from an obsidian egg....
A blue egg! Wow how rare! It might sell for more!
A green egg, eh? Not really sure if your Sim would like it... not with a fox... not in a box... not anywhere!
Orange you going to enjoy this egg?
All the colors of the rainbow in an egg!
It's a hatchable egg! Try to incubate this egg in a coop and you might see a chick hatch.\nHatchable eggs cannot be used as ingredients
This golden egg is hatchable! Could a Golden Chicken hatch from a golden egg?\nHatchable eggs cannot be used as ingredients
They say Charles hatched from an obsidian egg... It's possible this hatchable egg could carry on his legacy.\nHatchable eggs cannot be used as ingredients

When the world is bustling with buzzing phones, screaming screens, and unreturned emails, sometimes we must learn to take a lesson from our good friend the garden snail. It's time to slow down. Take a moment and enjoy this lovely stone and wood fireplace with a fellow Sim, or by yourself if you need a breath of solitude alone in your shell. Remember: snails don't answer their phones immediately, and you don't have to either.

Years ago in the days of yore and yesteryear, people used to have no place for their fires. They'd keep them wherever they could: the corner, the middle of the room, in a backpack. None of those were a good idea and led to many unhappy times and burnt eyebrows. Then one day, the idea came to have a place for the fire to live that was contained. Since it was a place to keep fire, it made sense to call it a fireplace, and thus began the tradition of keeping fire contained within a structure. Eureka!

An Old King Kool is a very old school
And a very old school is this fridge;
It calls for some ice
and it calls for a chisel
‘cause without this stuff you’ll get the diarrlizzle
Old King Kool - by The IceBox Corporation

All fridges work pretty much the same way. You put your stuff in it and the stuff gets cold. But the ReFridgeAdeezer is different. Not only will it make your stuff cold when you first put it in, it will also make your stuff just as cold after you take it out and put it back in again. No matter how long you leave it out. That’s how we built our blue ribbon reputation in the very competitive ReFrigeration industry. Plus we’ve added a handy freezer on top and a cool retro cottage look all over it. That should get you thinkin’ about stuff, huh?
For when crops need growing fast. A daily dose of this fertilizer will accelerate any crop through its life cycle and ready for harvest in time for that competition!
