Letting your garden ramble on and on... and on... is always tempting, but if you're someone who needs at least a small smidgeon of order amongst the wild sprawl of vegetation, this floral trellised gate might strike your fancy. Is it really the end of your garden, or is it just the beginning?

After his fall from the wall, Humpty Dumpty was incredibly traumatized and steered clear of walls until his therapist insisted he start doing exposure therapy. This process involved Humpty sitting on "wall-like" items to start, including this lovely gate. After sitting on gates, fences, and barriers, Humpty slowly felt more comfortable returning to walls.

Life in the country promotes community and togetherness, but boundaries are still nice. If you had none, neighbors would be raiding your vegetable gardens and borrowing sugar left and right. Chaos! This gate helps keep the peace while still being welcoming. After all, there is a big hole in the middle, so it's not exactly the Tower of London.
When your crop size needs a modest boost, look no further than this fertilizer. A daily dose can help encourage larger crops, or at least put a little extra heft on existing crops.
The finest formula of crop growth fertilizers. A daily dose of this stuff will put rocket boosters on your plant's size chance, or at the very least really kick the crop's weight into overdrive!

This fertilizer was built for the busy crop gardener who just needs more time. This formula is scientifically guaranteed to stop weed growth and keep bugs away! Simply sprinkle this fertilizer over your crops once every few days and remember to water your plants.

Is your crop plant looking sickly, or does its fruit need a little help reaching higher quality? Look no further! Sprinkle this fertilizer over your field once a day for a nice boost to the health of your plant and the quality of its yield.
Are you looking to supercharge the health of your crop? Sprinkle a daily dose of this fertilizer to make sure your plant is as healthy as possible and yields the highest quality crops.

It was a dark and stormy night when Christina Agate came to the town of Finchwick. She carried with her a wrought iron lantern that was a tad scuffed, but shone brightly nonetheless. She had come to Finchwick to solve the heinous crime of herbicide. Someone had ripped up all of the pubs herb garden and left a set of curious footprints. If there's anyone who could get to the bottom of this horrid scene, it was Christina.To be continued...
Dark and Stormy Night Ceiling Lantern Part 1 – by Bagatha Chrisptea

Detective Christina Agate shone her wrought iron lantern at the ground and took a long look at the set of footprints embedded in the soil. "That's odd." She exclaimed. There were two sets of footprints, both identical in weight. Solving the mystery of who obliterated this herb garden was going to take some thinking. Good thing her trusty lantern is by her side! Christina laid out a map of the town, as well as a giant corkboard of suspects interconnected with string. No one was going to get away with destroying the pub's prized herb garden while she was on the case! To be continued...
Dark and Stormy Night Ceiling Lantern Part 2 – by Bagatha Chrisptea

Detective Christina Agate had been in Finchwick for several days now poring over evidence from a brutal crime scene: the destruction of the pub's beloved herb garden. As she was staring at her homemade crime map of the vicinity and suspects, the storm knocked the power out. Thankfully, she still had her wrought iron lantern with her.\n "This doesn't make sense." Christina pondered. "Why would there be two sets of bootprints leading to and from the crime scene, both so evenly spaced? It's almost like the perpetrator was tied together with their partner in crime. But that's poppycock! Or is it?" Christina stared pensively out the window, holding up her lantern. "Aha! Of course!" She trekked over to the pasture across the way, and sure enough, spotted the criminal: a cow wearing two sets of wellington boots! "Mooo?" The cow's breath still smelled faintly of rosemary and thyme.\n"I've caught you, you naughty boot-wearing cow!" Christina broke the news to the farmer who owned the cow, and agreed to donate milk to the pub for free for a whole year. As for Christina's trusty lantern, she decided to gift it to the pub owners, and they decided to hang it from the ceiling. Mystery solved! Though no explanation was ever given for the boots. Mooooooo...
Dark and Stormy Night Ceiling Lantern Part 3 – by Bagatha Chrisptea

Years ago a peddler came to the town of Finchwick and offered a nice variety of items for surprisingly low prices. He claimed this chandelier was originally from a haunted opera house which was trashed after some "mischievous goings on." No one can be sure if the peddler was telling the truth or just read too much opera ghost fiction, but either way, it's a pretty little chandelier.

What were the "mysterious goings on" in the haunted opera house? Which opera house are we talking about? The Peddler's tales left the citizens of Henford-on-Bagley mesmerized... and a tad afraid. We think this is the perfect case for Detective Christina Agate, will she be able to solve this? We wished this was the case!

Pretty little chandelier or not, this lamp... well, the longer it is, the more terrified the citizens are of it. The Peddler reassured the townfolk that the lamps were safe, that he had traveled with them for years and nothing happened... but the doubt still remained even after he left all those years ago. The tales of the old opera house lamp remained as urban legend... but can we rest assured it is actually fiction? We may never get to know, maybe it is better that way.

From the folks that brought you the Tac Pencil, the Tac Beverage and the Tac Hat comes the new Tac Torch. It’s ideal for those times when using any other word to describe your stuff would sound much less impressive. The Tac Torch doesn’t just light up an area - it Tac lights up that area. So, don’t settle for anything less than the Tac thing. Anything else would be Tac less. Now where did I leave me torch? Oh, on the Tac Table.
The Tac Torch - by Tac Time Tactical

Years ago an eccentric dowager left her bed & breakfast inn The Frog's Wallow to her pet frogs after she passed away. Her will stipulated that the frogs were to dress in clothing and run the B&B. After it failed miserably due to frogs not being able to read calendars, cook, or speak, it became abandoned and items were auctioned off. These lovely botanical inspired sconces are some of the last remaining items to be salvaged. Supposedly the frogs used to congregate underneath them at dinnertime since they would attract delicious bugs. Ribbit!

When you ask most people about electricity, they'll say Thomas Edison or Benjamin Franklin "discovered" it, but did you know one of the first mentions of electricity was in books written by English scientists William Gilbert and Sir Thomas Browne in the 1600s? That's right. The English have that one too. Sorry, Americans. As a consolation prize, please accept this small electric lantern.
This pub sign is made out of fine matte wood. Perfect for listing specials or funny platitudes like “If you are looking for a sign you should have a glass of juice, this is it!”
This garden market shop is beloved by all with a green-thumb or penchant for plants. Also the gnomes! Buy or sell your plants and seeds here!

When it comes to farm fresh produce, come to Goldbloom's Grocery Shop. Kim knows a thing or two about spotting produce at its peak ripeness. How is she able to spot such perfectly ripe produce? Must be from eating all those perfect carrots. Stop by and buy or sell your produce today!

Hodgekiss Schmergg made a name for himself with a career in the oil on velvet genre. His early notable works consisted of the iconic Elton on Velvet, Vigo on Velvet, Matador in Rugby Shoes (on velvet) and culminating with his groundbreaking work “Dogs Playing Poker.” It would catapult him to his rightful place atop the world’s velvet stage. Now, for a limited time, you can own one of the Master of Modern Velvet’s collection of much cheaper, more obscure works from his Still Life with Stuff & Such series. Looks great in any cottage basement or rec room.
The Still Life with Stuff & Such Series - by Hodgekiss Schmergg

It's said that once upon a time a young girl used a basket just like this one to take delicious treats to her grandmother. We are not sure what happened to the girl, but the Fresh Breeze Picnic Basket is here for you! It can fit your meals and keep them fresh for longer!
They said it couldn't be done, but we did it. Slightly rounder, meet Yet Another Picnic Basket. It will keep your food fresh for longer, all while looking very cute.

Hey, diddle, diddle, a fiddle leaf fig will
Bring lots of life to your space
This little tree thrives in bright sunlight
And is sure to brighten your days

I spend too much time on me bum, or so says me mum.
She says trolly up all them triffids to pull for some walkies.
That’s when I says to me mum, “that seems awful dumb
when I could just sit here and eat all these chockies.
Posies in a Porcelain Pot. An alliterative avenue of action to achieve the amorous affections of an acquaintance.

Make sure all your days are good ones* (or at least give them a fighting chance of being pleasant) with these gorgeous hand-crafted flower boxes. Filled to the brim with daisies, they're sure to bring a smile to even the most sour-faced Sims. *Good days due to daisies not a guarantee. Flowers are to be used for aesthetic purposes only. Flower boxes do not prevent job loss, vampire bites, rain, angry gnomes, or hot-headed temper tantrums.

Attract wild rabbits with this cozy home, made with the latest in rabbit technology (which is surprisingly sophisticated for creatures without opposable thumbs). In addition to being super cute, rabbits will generously give gifts to Sims they like, and if asked by a friend, they'll help with gardening by devouring any weeds. Friendly rabbits will also donate their all-natural rabbit-made "fertilizer" to enrich the soil around Oversized Crops as part of their gardening services.
Unlock by befriending a Wild Rabbit\n\nRabbits can be found living inside cut down tree stumps in Henford-on-Bagley in The Bramblewood and Old New Henford
Unlocked by befriending a Wild Rabbit
A sure sign there's rabbit's afoot.

There's a lot of cool stuff you can put on top of this support beam, but they aren't included here. This is just a regular ole roof support beam with no particular hopes or dreams. Still, in order for the more interesting roof décor to not topple off your roof, you do need to start here. So remember that when you've finished adding all your cool roof décor. Remember the little roof beams in life that your roof décor is literally stepping on to get where they are today.
Run of the Mill Roof Support Beam

If your cottage is more than a few centuries old, it might be time to think about a stylish new hay cut for your roof. But just because you’re gonna upgrade doesn’t mean you can’t be kicking it old school with a Mullet Roof Toupee from the Hay experts at the Hay Club. Because with a mullet roof toupee from The Roof Club it’s gonna be all Business in the front and a Party in the back & sides. Don’t forget to ask about our whimsical roof toppers to further spiffify that mullet.
Mullett Roof Toupee – by The Hay Club

Let’s face it, if your cottage is several centuries old it might be experiencing premature straw loss on the old roof top. It’s nothing to be ashamed about. It happens to a lot of cottages that age. But that doesn’t mean you have to put up with it - or worse yet, try to cover it with an unsightly blue tarp. Not anymore! Because with a roof toupee from The Hay Club you’ll have that roof full of silky, shiny new hay you’ve always wanted. Any other doo just wouldn’t do. Don’t forget to ask about our whimsical roof toppers too.
Bowl Cut Roof Toupee – by The Hay Club

Oh give me a home where the bunnies all roam. Where the gnome and the coney all play. Yeah, those lyrics and these roof toppers take me back to the summer I spent at the ConeyRanch at WestSouthfordThorpeShire, watching those tenacious rodeo gnomes getting bucked off the backs of those stick bunnies. Those wild hares may be made of sticks but they just can’t be tamed. Finally, you can relive those precious memories by adorning the roof of your quaint cottage with a reasonable facsimile thanks to Stick Figures Inc.
Bucking Bunnies – by Stick Figures Inc.

My buddy Rod use to tell me that in life, it’s all about love (“the Kwan”) not the almighty coin. I’d have to agree with that. But sometimes you really need to show me the bunny! Now that would complete me. These particular bunny’s had me at hello. You’ll love them too.
Show me the Bunny! - by TomKo Roof Ornamentation

Dotted with bunnies, foxes, and mushrooms or sumptuous florals, this rug brings the essence of Bramblewood forest into your home without having to sweep up after it. Have you ever had four rabbits and two foxes running around in your place? Trust us, the rug is much easier to clean.
This special Livestock Upgrade Part can be used to upgrade Animal Sheds or Coops! To find more of these complete errands from locals in town!

That’s Rex with the long ears and bandana atop the barrel. He’s putting together another of his posh displays for one of the upscale businesses in the village. His creations are reminiscent of a jauntier time style from around the turn of the century. Captivating, don’t you think? Inexplicably though Rex would destroy his freshly styled signage only to start it over again. I guess he’d get a wild hare or something.

These metal posts hold banners of all kinds! Birthday, new babies, welcome backs, festivals, and festivals about banners! It can hold it all. After much testing in the ole metal post lab, we suggest getting two since they hold banners better than just one.

As I entered, I thought, “this is the strangest Porta Potty I’ve ever seen”. No lavvy, a dog & bone on the wall and so many windows – this can’t be a loo. I figured it must be some kinda tiny house or something. As I left, my head was spinning and I was still no closer to my original goal. Naturally I headed to the pub where it was explained to me by a rather odd, curly haired chap that I had it all wrong. It was in fact an ancient time machine that had been painted red. Roaming charges may apply.

It wasn’t like Smitty to turn up late for work but Smitty ain’t exactly what you’d call a “morning bird”. Besides, traffic was a mess on the 405 and by the time Smitty had clocked in, the sun was already breakin’ over the henhouse. Smitty had to act fast to get farmer Wilson out of bed in time to feed all the animals. So, he boldly kicked over the watering can, vaulted atop and crowed with everything he had. Farmer Wilson was so impressed by Smitty’s perseverance that he had a fountain built to mark the occasion. Yep, this is it.
Wake Up and Spill the Water

Once upon a time there were four little pigs who were sent out into the world to seek their fortunes. The first little pig was a tad lazy and built his house of straw. The second little pig was also a little lazy built his house out of sticks. The third little pig worked very hard to build his home out of bricks. The fourth little pig decided to go to a trade school for construction and built his home out of wood with gorgeous shingled windows, the latter of which is shown here. He took great pride in his work, and rightly so! No wolf is going to blow this roof window down anytime soon.
The Fourth Little Pig Roof Window

Forget living in the fast lane, live in a storybook! It just takes one or two of these adorable recessed cottage-style roof windows to make your everyday feel like the page of a fable. So watch out for talking wolves, break out the porridge, and dust off your tuffet.
Even your roof windows need a new hairdo every now and then! This cute, sassy thatched roof provides a cozy cottage look and proves that bowl cuts are back in style. Were they ever out of style?
Thatch, Natch! Roof Window Style - By the Hay Club
Most commonly purple, the spongy, absorbent fruit is used in several cuisines. Typically used as a vegetable in cooking, it is a berry by botanical definition.
Lettuce is most often used for salads, although it is also seen in other kinds of food, such as soups, sandwiches and wraps; it can also be grilled.
A cultivar of winter squash that is round with smooth, slightly ribbed skin, and is most often deep yellow to orange in coloration.
A watermelon, is not simple a water melon, it is a highly cultivated fruit worldwide, with more than 1,000 varieties.

Remember Rex the Hare stylist? This bunny is an exact copy of Rex. Why would we do that? Because in accordance with local, interplanetary, and Sims law, we are required to make anything this cute available to the public as a separate object. Heck! We were gonna give him to you as a separate object for free anyway ‘cause he’s just so darn precious! So, please enjoy your bonus bunny.
Bonus Bunny – by Sims Modelers Inc.

Meet your new favorite cannisters! Brighten up any countertop while reminding yourself to eat more fruit, or get the kind without fruit on them... but if you do that, please do remember to eat fruit. You don't want to get scurvy. Once you get scurvy you kind of have to become a pirate to go along with the look, and that's a whole thing. Tri corner hats are hard to find, so, be nice to yourself and eat more fruit.

This cast iron cookware has been passed down through the Arthur family for nearly 15 generations - Ever since he yanked that pot from that stone. Which, by the by, turned out to be a pretty fair day for Arthur in the long run, - Don’t you think? Even after being around for like, a long time, the pot still looks brand-spankin' new. This is truly a brilliant enchanted piece of iron. Get one for your round table today and live the legend.
The Kings Cookware – by The Merlin Forge

Meet Herb. He’s been a perennial favorite in all the gardens of Verdure-Boscage on ShrubsBerry for several hundred years. Seems as though Herb has a way with the posies. They bloom bigger than a corgi’s head and the locals swear it’s due to his magical powers. They also think his festive hat is just the cat’s jammies. Invite Herb into your garden today. He’d dig it if you did.

We thought having the complete set would help solve the mystery of the famous technologist and tea aficionado, but no luck here. This beautiful Tea Set embodies the countryside aesthetic not only in the artistry and colors, but even in the small details such as its beautiful tray made out of real wood, directly carved from a tree!

Everybody is always nagging me, “Use your words, use your words!” Well, if I had the time & my boss would let me, I’d write, like, a lot of words to describe just how awesome this item happens to be. But why would I? It’s a pitcher. And everybody knows that, according to local guidelines, a pitcher is worth a thousand words. Right? It’s a cool pitcher, though.

There is an inscription in this Teapot that reads: This Teapot is not short or stout. Keeps your Tea fresh and hot, enjoy with a biscuit while you brunch It seems signed even... maybe the owner's name? But it's unreadable. Rumour has it that this Teapot belonged to a famous technologist and tea aficionado, maybe one day we will decrypt this mystery?
If installing vents in your home gives you butterflies - this is the perfect ventilation solution for you! Complete with a whimsical butterfly, this vent will leave you feeling aflutter.

Feeling blue because it's not the right season for door wreaths? We say: Free the Wreath! Don't let society dictate when door wreaths are acceptable. Think outside the wreath-box! This playful blueberry wreath celebrates the berry bounty of Spring and Summer and looks stunning on any door, year-round.
A ribbon awarded at the Finchwick Fair's Chicken Competition.
A ribbon awarded at the Finchwick Fair's Cow Competition.
A ribbon awarded at the Finchwick Fair's Oversized Crop Competition.
First Place Oversized Crop Competition Ribbon
Second Place Oversized Crop Competition Ribbon
Third Place Oversized Crop Competition Ribbon
A ribbon awarded at the Finchwick Fair's Garden Competition.
A ribbon awarded at the Finchwick Fair's Egg Competition.
A ribbon awarded at the Finchwick Fair's Llama Competition.
A ribbon awarded at the Finchwick Fair's Milk Competition.
A ribbon awarded at the Finchwick Fair's Pie Competition.
A ribbon awarded at the Finchwick Fair's Wool Competition.

If you're into foraging, you might fancy this shelf! It's got plenty of room to hang bushels of anything you bring back, including fresh herbs. Some sage advice? This shelf is kind of a big dill, so grab one while you can before thyme runs out! It was clearly mint to be.

A worn shovel. A canvas bag. A damp aluminium watering can. Hung all too neatly from the modest wooden shelf on the cottage wall. But what did it all mean? The clues all pointed to the freshly turned soil in the garden. Why tea plants? Had a crime been perpetrated? If so, whodunnit? Solve the mystery for yourself when you purchase the Whodunnit Shelf. The latest in the series of Christina Agate mysteries by Bagatha Chrisptea. Comes complete with a bag 'a crisps and tea.
Store everything you need to cook up some toad in the 'ole, sheperd's pie, bangers 'n mash, beans on toast, a nice pudding, and of course, chicken tikka masala!
Eat Your Heart Out Kitchen Shelf

So, I has me a gander across the car park and blimey, I gets gobsmacked by a sign offering scrummy lookin’ pies. So, feelin’ quite peckish, I’m over there quicker than you can say Bob’s your uncle. I has me a slice and it was just brilliant. “Aces”, I tells the noshery shopkeep, aces.

The Henford-on-Bagley Community Information Sign is the best place to go to get information on any upcoming Finchwick Fair! Read the Fair Flyer and discover which competitions will be held each week. You can also learn more about the local villagers who make up the community.

The smaller the town, the larger the gathering, and the bigger the dish pile. If you find yourself staring at a mountain of dishes taller than a llama's eye, at least make sure your sink is up to the job. This one's got a nice big basin for easy washing, and also a cockerel to remind you to cock-a-doodle-do your dishes in a timely manner!

Always be wary of putting things on pedestals. You wouldn't want to experience that sinking feeling of disappointment...unless it's this sweet pedestal sink! You can put this on a pedestal as much as you want and it will always live up to expectations as long as the water's turned on.
Put it on a Pedestal Sink

Have a seat on this bubbly barstool and reminisce about the times you enjoyed a nice pint of juice and some good 'ol Toad In The Hole with your mates down at the Gnome's Arms. Barstools don't judge ya for drinking juice during the day, and they're great conversation partners if you just want someone to listen.

In the olden days, chairs were made for brief bouts of sitting, but never for lounging, lollygagging or lazing. There were just too many chores to be done for any of that nonsense. It wasn't until Lawrence the Loafer graced Henford-on-Bagley with his leisurely presence that folk started taking to the idea of having a nice long sit. Lawrence the Loafer tied a cushion to a simple wooden chair and suddenly, he was the talk of the town. Buns all over were supported and cushioned, and for the first time, the country way of life was once again peaceful and relaxing. So the next time you sink onto a comfy cushiony seat, remember the chair that started it all.
Lawrence the Loafer's Cushioned Country Chair

Also known as a toadstool, with reason, this ottoman is the more realistic depiction of the mushrooms that Farddsworth Dingleman sprouted... on his bum, as the prophecy foretold. This part of the collection by FanniFungi is more for those who enjoy the realism without sacrificing comfort. Give one a sit, just don't try to eat it.
Made of Henford pure organic, non fictional hay, this hay bale may not ergonomically correct, but it sure is aesthetically pleasing.

This story begins with the unusual case of Farddsworth Dingleman, a chap from the village of South Buetoxfordshire on Soggy Bottom just west of Giggleswick. It seem that Farddsworth, a well known lay about, spent most of his life sitting around doing nothing. As a result, over the years, he began sprouting mushrooms on his bum. Oddly, this was the inspiration for a highly successful new collection of ottomans by FanniFungi Furniture. One never knows where inspiration grows. Give one a sit today!

The ideal spot to plop your rear and read your favorite novel! Whether you're a fan of the Christina Agate mystery series, Charles Doinkens, or Virginia Hound, this chair lets you sink into whatever your chosen escapism is. Don't forget a nice cuppa!

This sofa has quite a pedigree. Once a predominant fixture in the rec rooms of 7 different monarchies. Then proudly spilled on in the dorm rooms of Dartford, OxFred, Stanbridge, Yayel, Westnorthern, UCIM, and the School of Hard Knocks just to name a few. It’s even circumnavigated the globe some 22 times with 14 different explorers. It’s safe to say that this sofa has seen more posterior than a city double decker seat. Yet gaze upon it. Why, it’s as pristine as the day it was hand crafted by the furniture gnomes of North Havaseat. I guess they just don’t make them like they used to. Find out for yourself and continue its lineage.
Cottagecore may celebrate simpler living, but there is nothing simple about these tunes.

Forged in the early 1900s, this antique iron stove can cook anything you throw at it, from curries to crumpets. Though you probably shouldn't throw curries or crumpets around so frivolously. One-eyed Rob lost his eye due to a crumpet misfire, but that's a story for another day. Anyway, enjoy this tank-like behemoth of a cooker. They don't make 'em like they used to.

Once a year, on ghost appreciation day, the tables at the Sir Conan O’Brian Arthur Doyle Inn at Barkersville get all dressed up in ghostly costume to revel in a truly unusual experience of the paranormal variety. The legend originated the night the tables turned on the good residents of Barkersville Manor. At the dinner hour, everyone had been seated and served around a large round table when a bone chilling scream rang out! It seems that Lady Doyle had ordered chips with her fish and had gotten mashed instead. That was what Sir Doyle had ordered. In fact everyone had been served the dish meant for the person to the right of them. Suddenly, the table bolted straight up off the ground, paused for a moment and slowly rotated slightly counter-clockwise and softly returned to the floor. Happy but a bit rattled, everyone enjoyed what they had ordered.
The Ghost Tables of the Barkersvilles

This table's seen plenty of good times down at the village pub... and plenty of not-so-good times as well. It's a bit worn around the edges, has one slightly wobbly leg, but can still perform table-y duties with great aplomb. The perfect place to start the day off right with a full English breakfast (don't forget the black pudding!), or end the day with a nice pudding and a pint of juice.

This end table was salvaged from an old B&B called The Frog's Wallow that was torn down years ago. It was previously owned by an eccentric dowager who left the estate to her pet frogs after she passed away. Her will stipulated that the frogs were to dress in clothing and run the B&B. While the plan was quite whimsical on paper and drew in lots of business initially, people soon realized frogs are not well suited to run an establishment. Instead of tending to the daily duties of the inn, the frogs just sat around in ill-fitted suits, hopping around the premises and peeing on guests whenever they were picked up. Fun fact: frog pee is cold. There's something you don't learn in school.\nLong story short, after the B&B went under, all the furniture was auctioned off, including this adorable table.

Great for sprucing up your hallway and has ample room for storage. If you wanted to, you could probably cram yourself into that bottom drawer.* A big selling point for any competetive hide-and-seek players. *Please do not attempt to climb into any drawers. Always play hide-and-seek safely!
Entitles the bearer to one (1) free grocery delivery service - please redeem coupon with the delivery Sim after accepting delivery to receive a refund on the delivery fee. Non-transferable.
A personal package to be delivered by hand.

Wedding season in Henford-on-Bagley wouldn't be complete without a traditional Henford wedding arch! Crafted from the finest branches and florals Bramblewood has to offer, this stunning arch lets locals and visitors alike celebrate their happy day as close to nature as can be. In the olden days, at the end of the marriage ceremony, the village's plumpest hen was trained to run under the archway to signify the start of the celebration. The newly married couple chased the hen into the fields where the dancing began, starting with the customary Henford Hop followed by the Bagley Barn Dance.
Made of 100% Henford Stone. No filler! This cute stone-trimmed window has a lovely diamond motif. Great for peeking, glimpsing, gazing, spying, and wistfully sighing.

Henford-on-Bagley is famous for rolling hillsides, fresh farm produce, and of course, big blocks of appropriately named Henford stone. For hundreds of years, the locals have been working with this stone, putting in long head-scratching hours of figuring out how to mine, transport and carve it. Thankfully, you don't have to do any of the manual labor, you just have to figure out the best place to put your new window.

Henford-on-Bagley is famous for rolling hillsides, fresh farm produce, and of course, big blocks of appropriately named Henford stone. For hundreds of years, the locals have been working with this stone, putting in long head-scratching hours of figuring out how to mine, transport and carve it. Thankfully, you don't have to do any of the manual labor, you just have to figure out the best place to put your new window.\nNow in circular!

A gorgeous window design accentuated by an arch of Henford stone, creating a lovely halo effect. Does the halo make the window "better"? The answer is yes. This window always remembers birthdays, pays its bills on time, and would eat its vegetables if it could.

A smaller version of the Henford Square Stone Trim Window, crafted by artisan stone workers, artisan glass workers, and non union wood workers, the latter of which just can't seem to get their act together to unionize. Adds a rustic charm to any home or cottage.
Small Henford Stone Square Trim Window

This fine window was first seen lining the Archduke of Windowbury's home over five hundred years ago. You might think that's a long time for a window to still be doing its thing, but this one was taken care of remarkably well. In old Windowbury, windows were prized more than any other home feature. This is probably due to the fact that citizens of Windowbury county have always been quite nosy, and love peeking in on their neighbors. Regardless of the whys, this window is a win.

These charming stained glass windows bring light and liveliness to any proud countryside residence or anyone wanting to bring an accent of the countryside to their home... wherever they may be. Perfect for any homeowner wanting to make a statement about their fondness for nature, or just wanting the world to know "hey, I'm cool with bugs."

Legend has it the stones used to make this window came from Henford Henge - an old stone lith circle that used to exist until the locals started mining it for stones to make windows like these. It was a pretty cool ancient historical site, but hey...windows are important too...right?

What good is living in the country if you can't let the fresh air in? This diamond-lattice window allows for the sweet country air to come through without letting in the rest of those pesky elements. Being able to crack open a window is just the kind of out-of-the-box thinking you'll find here at Wee Windows Inc. Innovation!
Sweet Country Air Window by Wee Windows Inc.

Have we got a dainty window for you! This window may look slightly larger than our usual offerings but we can assure you it still has that dainty demeanor you know and love from all our products. Crafted from local Bramblewood Forest trees, it's latticed diamond pattern and little cottage-style shutter will have you remarking "I can't believe how quaint and dainty this window is!" every time you see it. Teeny weeny little detailed cutouts offer a peephole style view of the outside world, but who even cares when you can admire this window?
The Daintiest Window (Left) by Wee Windows Inc.

Have we got a dainty window for you! This window may look slightly larger than our usual offerings but we can assure you it still has that dainty demeanor you know and love from all our products. Crafted from local Bramblewood Forest trees, it's latticed diamond pattern and little cottage-style shutter will have you remarking "I can't believe how quaint and dainty this window is!" every time you see it. Teeny weeny little detailed cutouts offer a peephole style view of the outside world, but who even cares when you can admire this window?
The Daintiest Window (Right) by Wee Windows Inc.

Thatched roofs started becoming a thing back in the neolithic time when agriculture was first starting to develop. Wild vegetation was used to line the roofs of windows such as this bay window. Back in those days, villagers used to have raucous thatching parties where everyone would get together and thatch each others roofs. Oh, those were the days. Staying up late, braiding each other's thatched roofs whilst talking about secret crushes on farmhands. Makes ye yearn for those simpler times...but this twee bay window's the next best thing.

Open a window to your next adventure! Whether you're anxiously peering outside for an exciting quest to come your way, or are just looking for a good source of light to read about such adventures from the comforts of your own home, this window is all you need. Now available in left AND right!
Storybook Cottage Window (Left) by Wee Windows Inc.

Open a window to your next adventure! Whether you're anxiously peering outside for an exciting quest to come your way, or are just looking for a good source of light to read about such adventures from the comforts of your own home, this window is all you need. Now available in right AND left!
Storybook Cottage Window (Right) by Wee Windows Inc.

What light through yonder window breaks? Why it's the light seen from your brand new double shuttered cottage window! How could we not wax poetically about the way the light trickles into this diamond-lattice patterned beauty? Shakespeare would surely have written sonnet upon sonnet about its adorable peephole cutout, iron detailing, and vibrant color selection. We'd like to think so, anyway.

The slightly larger version of our beautiful diamond-lattice patterned window, complete with peephole cutout and iron detailing. You might say this is the unabridged version! Shakespeare would approve.
Slightly Larger Sonnet-Worthy Double Shuttered Window
Keep your thirst for bay windows at bay with this bay window! Great for staring at bays, bay trees, docking bays, or anxiously awaiting for your bae.

Michael's always found more comfort in the company of animals than with other Sims, which can make for awkward dates but serves him well as the Bramblewood's creature keeper. After fixing up a run-down cottage in the woods many years ago, he's been the informal caretaker of the various plants and animals that call this place home ever since.

Raising Rahul as a single mom hasn't been easy, but Lavina has grown to love the relationship, as well as the pleasure she gets out of keeping the village running smoothly and being a good neighbor. Rahul looks up to his capable mother, but after living in this small village all his life, yearns to travel and see the world. He can't quite bring himself to leave his mom all on her own, though.

The best part of living in cozy Henford-on-Bagley for Kim is the fact that she gets to meet so many new friends, from spirited little Maira to that dreamy Michael Bell. The grocery stall is also a matter of pride for her: a central hub of social activity and quality produce. Having seen this village through its ups and downs, Kim is always eager to hear the news of what's been happening in the lives of her customers.

Located just across from the ruins on the Isle of Volpe, this park is the perfect start for any Bramblewood adventure. Then enjoy a meal at the grill, find or leave a present under Sophie the Snail, relax beside the serene Cordelia Falls, explore the ruins, charm the local wildlife, or go foraging for wild mushrooms and berries. The only problem will be doing it all before the sun goes down!

The perfect rental for any Sim wanting to visit Henford-on-Bagley, 13 Nettle Lane combines the natural charms of the surrounding Bramblewood with the updated conveniences of a contemporary renovation. Enjoy exploring the ruins on the nearby Isle of Volpe, finding local wildlife in the yard, or heading down the road to Old New Henford's community garden or Finchwick's weekly fair.

This old family home is buried deep in the Bramblewood, surrounded by the forest's furry and feathered inhabitants. Like a sturdy yew tree, it's a home that has stood the test of time, with sturdy roots, decades of memories, and a few fresh additions as the years have passed.

After working an office job for more years than he'd care to admit, Derek found a man willing to live the rustic dream of his youth and the two moved to his family cottage and never left. When not fending off financial offers from developers who see their home as a prime target, Ian and Derek balance their days between adventure and quiet, depending on who's in charge of the agenda. Despite - or perhaps because of - their differences, time has been most kind to these elderly lovebirds, who live a contented retirement as key members of the Henford-on-Bagley community.

Those willing to make the hike up Cordelia Falls are rewarded with an enchanting secret. Nestled neatly near the top of the falls and rumored to have once secretly housed young royals on holiday, this small cottage is the perfect hideaway to enjoy nature, fish, and relax amidst the Bramblewood.

This cozy home sits in the heart of Finchwick and is steps away from the small village's community hub. Though it can get a bit loud on fair days, there's no better place for a Sim who wants to be a part of it all.

As owners of The Gnome's Arms, Finchwick's beloved pub, the Scotts are living the dream! Well, Sara's dream at least. Simon - a city boy with no more city around - still feels a bit awkward every time he runs into a chicken. Still, he's here to support his wife's dream. Will their hopes of adding a new member to their tiny family changes things up for better or worse?

This stone-built pub is the local hangout of choice around Finchwick, and it's not surprising to see folks from the entire surrounding Henford-on-Bagley area here. Head upstairs to watch a little football on the telly or enjoy some delicious local fare at the bar downstairs - either way, it's clear what makes this place a community favorite.
This pragmatic village home is planted directly across Cobblebottom Street from Finchwick's garden walkways, making it the ideal place for a botanic-minded Sim to settle down.

Don't be scared away by the fact that this cozy but cluttered home has been on the market for longer than normal. It may suffer from what some have deemed an "excess of character," but that only means it's simply waiting for the right Sim to come and find it - a Sim looking to live their one wild and precious life in the quaint village of Finchwick.

The centerpiece of Old New Henford, this sizeable estate sits perched at the top of Olde Mill Hill and has been part of the Watson family for generations. There's almost too much land for one family to tend, though the sprawling gardens and yard leave plenty of room for growing a variety of crops and keeping a bevy of animals.

Inheriting the family estate was always the plan, but Thomas may be in over his head. For a man who equates success with crop size, he's losing both his confidence and his family. While his wife Rahmi loves the country air, her feelings for her husband are becoming stale and her affections have wandered. The oldest of their three children, Rashidah, feels trapped, preferring to dream of a future outside Henford-on-Bagley - dreams that have sparked something between her and a kindred soul. The two youngest couldn't be more different! Imran treasures the security of life at home while Maira can be found bravely venturing out into the unknown. Will this hectic family come together or fall apart in their "old new" home?
2 Olde Mill Lane is an empty plot of idyllic country land, lying in wait for any Sim with a dream to transform it into the ideal home.
Sitting riverside in Old New Henford, this sizable home boasts lots of land for growing, whether a Sim is looking to grow plants, animals, or their family.

A fusion of Old New Henford's historic past and cool present, this old barn has been completely refurbished into a cottage home. Tucked privately between the edge of the Bramblewood and the River Bagley, a Sim could easily forget that the rest of the world exists while in its quaint garden.

After living in the big city and having her heart broken, Cecilia decided to ditch everything she knew for a small garden plot and some chickens. She's still looking for someone to share this life with, though after a date she'd love to forget with local Creature Keeper Michael Bell, she's happy to only form long-term attachments with the critters that visit for now.
Stop Gardening Help for All Rabbit Residents

Oh, I knew I could count on that Creature Keeper! Mushrooms! And a charming mushroom, no less! I can certainly take a hint and I do appreciate your help and discretion in all of this.
If I give these berries and mushrooms a bit of a mash, we'll have a concoction that'll be sure to twist your taste buds. Here, give this a taste!
Oh this will do nicely for what I have in mind. Come see me at the bar and I'll concoct a little something I'm calling a Bagley Berry Fizz that's bursting with berries!
Delightful! These mushrooms look particularly pungent. Visit me at the bar, and I'll craft them into an earthy drink with a kick to it. I call it the Verdant and Funk.

This is a beautiful flower but I'm left wondering if the Grocery Owner has incorrect notions about us. Give them my regards and... oh, let me give you these Charming and Verdant Mushrooms to take to them, as a way to return the favor. They can be a gift. Or not? I leave it up to you! I don't want to send the wrong signals.
Thank goodness! I've been lugging this package around for the Mayor, and just waiting for someone to come collect it. Please see that it gets to them.
Hmmm... sorry, I don't know what package you're talking about.
You've got the wrong Sim! I have nothing for you.
Sorry to disappoint, but another villager must have your package.
Didn't you already ask me? I told you, I don't have your package!
I think you've got the wrong Sim! I'm not expecting any package.
Keep looking, because that package is quite certainly not mine.
You again? I do enjoy presents, but I must insist that this package is not mine.

I've always felt quite close with the Mayor and I feel like I seek their approval before I make big choices. I don't know if they'd approve of me wanting to leave Henford-on-Bagley, a place that's always meant so much to them.\n\nOh, I know! Do you think you could make a cross-stitch for them and ask them for me? I'd be quite grateful.
I'm a few eggs short and got pies to make, so two eggs please!
I'd like to place an order for three eggs.
Oh, I'm low on eggs! Put me down for a few.
You want to know about... my dreams? I suppose I've always let my mind wander with fantasies about travel, adventure, and being somewhere other than the small village I grew up in.

The gnome stumbled across two villagers doing what inside an Animal Shed?! Oh my; you'll make an old lady blush! I can't wait to tell the hens about this in our cross-stitch meet up.
They all want eggs?! I'll need at least a dozen more eggs to fill these orders. Can you go and find them for me?

Yikes! You're almost as scary as that grumpy old Crumplebottom! I'm still not entirely sure what I did wrong, but it'd almost be an abnormal day if I didn't get a scolding from her.

Make By: This is the standard egg that hens lay. You can also feed a Hen a "Friendly Treat" Animal Treat to ensure the next egg they lay will be white.\n
Used For: The ideal ingredient for egg-based recipes, without any unwanted side effects.\n
Rarity: Common

Rarity: Common

Make By: Assigning a Rooster and Hen to the same Chicken Coop will give Hens a chance to lay Hatchable Eggs. \n
Used For: These eggs can be incubated in a coop to hatch a Chick. Nesting Hens will decrease the amount of time it takes to hatch, as well as increase the quality of the egg. This will make the Chick happier when they hatch! Hatchable Eggs cannot be used in recipes.\n
Rarity: Common
Can't wait to see what this little egg grows up to be!

Make By: Happy Chickens that have a good relationship with Sims in the household have a chance of laying Hatchable Golden Eggs.\n
Used For: Hatchable Golden Eggs will hatch a Golden Chick or Rooster. Incubate in a Chicken Coop to hatch. Golden Chicks will not manifest Golden Pulse Powers until they are fully grown. Cannot be used in recipes.
Rarity: Rare
Glittering gold and full of life!

Make By: Happy Chickens that do not have a good relationship with its owners have a chance to lay Hatchable Obsidian Eggs.\n
Used For: Can be incubated in a Chicken Coop to hatch the embodiment of evil in the form of an adorable Chick. Evil Chicks will not manifest Evil Pulse Powers until they are fully grown. These cannot be used in recipes.\n
Rarity: Rare

Make By: Hens that are Very Happy, but have a really bad relationship with one of their owners have a chance to lay an Obsidian Egg. Evil Hens that are Happy will always lay an Obsidian Egg.\n
Used For: Hatchable Obsidian Eggs can hatch an Evil Chicken. Using an Obsidian Egg to prepare Eggs and Toast, Scrambled Eggs, or an Omelet can have... interesting... side effects.\n
Rarity: Rare

Make By: Feed a Hen a "Pumpkin Treat" Animal Treat and the next egg they lay will be orange.\n
Used For: Orange Eggs are used to complete certain errands for the Grocery Owner and Grocery Delivery villagers that live in Henford-on-Bagley.\n
Rarity: Common

Make By: Chickens that are Very Happy have a chance to lay a Rainbow Egg. Alternatively, feed a Hen a "Rainbow Treat" Animal Treat and the next egg they lay will be rainbow.\n
Used For: Rainbow Eggs are used to create the "Rainbow Treat" Animal Treat.\n
Rarity: Rare

Make By: Aubergine seeds can be ordered by Purchasing Oversized Crop Seeds on a computer. Aubergines can only be planted in a Garden Patch, which can be acquired in Build Mode. The care shown when growing an Aubergine will affect its final weight and quality.
Improved By: Experiment on Aubergines in your garden by using different fertilizers, which can be purchased from the Garden Shop in Finchwick, or received when completing errands for villagers in Henford-on-Bagley.
Used For: By increasing your cooking skill, Aubergines can be Canned and turned into Aubergine Conserves - an ingredient used in the preparation of certain recipes. Aubergines can also be taken to the Finchwick Fair and submitted to the Oversized Crop competition by using the competition pedestal for a chance at fabulous prizes!
Rarity: Common

Make By: Mushroom seeds can be ordered by Purchasing Oversized Crop Seeds on a computer. Mushrooms can only be planted in a Garden Patch, which can be acquired in Build Mode. The care shown when growing a Mushroom will affect its final weight and quality.
Improved By: Experiment on Mushrooms in your garden by using different fertilizers, which can be purchased from the Garden Shop in Finchwick, or received when completing errands for villagers in Henford-on-Bagley.
Used For: By increasing your cooking skill, Mushrooms can be Canned and turned into Mushroom Conserves - an ingredient used in the preparation of certain recipes. Mushrooms can also be taken to the Finchwick Fair and submitted to the Oversized Crop competition by using the competition pedestal for a chance at fabulous prizes!
Rarity: Common

Make By: Lettuce seeds can be ordered by Purchasing Oversized Crop Seeds on a computer. Lettuce can only be planted in a Garden Patch, which can be acquired in Build Mode. The care shown when growing Lettuce will affect its final weight and quality.
Improved By: Experiment on Lettuce in your garden by using different fertilizers, which can be purchased from the Garden Shop in Finchwick, or received when completing errands for villagers in Henford-on-Bagley.
Used For: By increasing your cooking skill, Lettuce can be Canned and turned into Lettuce Conserves - an ingredient used in the preparation of certain recipes. Lettuce can also be taken to the Finchwick Fair and submitted to the Oversized Crop competition by using the competition pedestal for a chance at fabulous prizes!
Rarity: Common

Make By: Pumpkin seeds can be ordered by Purchasing Oversized Crop Seeds on a computer. Pumpkins can only be planted in a Garden Patch, which can be acquired in Build Mode. The care shown when growing a Pumpkin will affect its final weight and quality.
Improved By: Experiment on Pumpkins in your garden by using different fertilizers, which can be purchased from the Garden Shop in Finchwick, or received when completing errands for villagers in Henford-on-Bagley.
Used For: By increasing your cooking skill, Pumpkins can be Canned and turned into Pumpkin Conserves - an ingredient used in the preparation of certain recipes. Pumpkins can also be taken to the Finchwick Fair and submitted to the Oversized Crop competition by using the competition pedestal for a chance at fabulous prizes!
Rarity: Common
Technically, pumpkins are squash, gourds, and fruit. A marvel of nature!

Make By: Watermelon seeds can be ordered by Purchasing Oversized Crop Seeds on a computer. Watermelons can only be planted in a Garden Patch, which can be acquired in Build Mode. The care shown when growing a Watermelon will affect its final weight and quality.
Improved By: Experiment on Watermelons in your garden by using different fertilizers, which can be purchased from the Garden Shop in Finchwick, or received when completing errands for villagers in Henford-on-Bagley.
Used For: By increasing your cooking skill, Watermelons can be Canned and turned into Watermelon Conserves - an ingredient used in the preparation of certain recipes. Watermelons can also be taken to the Finchwick Fair and submitted to the Oversized Crop competition by using the competition pedestal for a chance at fabulous prizes!
Rarity: Common
Has the Sledge-O-Matic met its match?

Make By: This is the standard milk that cows provide. You can also feed a cow a "Friendly Treat" to remove the side effects from other treats, and ensure that the next time they're milked that they will provide good ole' standard Milk. Happier cows provide higher quality Milk.\n
Used For: A tasty beverage. Also the ideal ingredient for recipes that incorporate Milk, without any unwanted side effects. (Lactose-intolerant Sims should seek out Mighty Plant Milk.)\n
Rarity: Common

Make By: Feed a cow a "Midnight Treat" Animal Treat and they'll provide Obsidian Milk when milked. Happier cows provide higher quality Obsidian Milk.\n
Used For: Drinking Obsidian Milk can have... interesting... side effects.\n
Rarity: Rare

Make By: Feed a cow a "Fruity Treat" Animal Treat and they'll provide Enriched Milk when milked. Alternatively, tip your cow for Enriched Milk. Happier cows provide higher quality Enriched Milk.\n
Used For: Drinking Enriched Milk will provide faster skill gain for a period of time.\n
Rarity: Common

Make By: Feed a cow a "Chocolatey Treat" Animal Treat and they'll provide Chocolate Milk when milked. Happier cows provide higher quality Chocolate Milk.\n
Used For: Drinking Chocolate Milk is pure happiness in a bottle.\n
Rarity: Uncommon

Make By: Feed a cow a "Golden Treat" Animal Treat and they'll provide Golden Honey Milk when milked. Happier cows provide higher quality Golden Honey Milk.\n
Used For: Drinking Golden Honey Milk can have... powerful... side effects.\n
Rarity: Rare

Make By: Feed a cow a "Veggie Treat" Animal Treat and they'll provide Mighty Plant Milk when milked. Happier cows provide higher quality Mighty Plant Milk.\n
Used For: Safely enjoyed by Lactose Intolerant Sims. Drinking Mighty Plant Milk will provide muscle gain, faster Fitness Skill gain, and slows the effects of Aging. Mighty Plant Milk can also be used as an ingredient in Lactose-free recipes.\n
Rarity: Common

Make By: Feed a cow a "Pumpkin Treat" Animal Treat and they'll provide Pumpkin Spice Milk when milked. Happier cows provide higher quality Pumpkin Spice Milk.\n
Used For: Drinking Pumpkin Spice Milk will provide faster Gardening Skill gain for a period of time.\n
Rarity: Common
A flavor loved by basic people everywhere.

Make By: Feed a cow a "Flirty Treat" Animal Treat and they'll provide Strawberry Milk when milked. Happier cows provide higher quality Strawberry Milk.\n
Used For: Drinking Strawberry Milk will surface a Sim's innermost desires.\n
Rarity: Uncommon

Make By: Feed a cow a "Rainbow Treat" Animal Treat and they'll provide Rainbow Milk when milked. Happier cows provide higher quality Rainbow Milk.\n
Used For: Drinking Rainbow Milk is like embarking on a playful adventure!\n
Rarity: Rare

Make By: Feed a cow a "Spicy Treat" Animal Treat and they'll provide Fire Milk when milked. Happier cows provide higher quality Fire Milk.\n
Used For: Drinking Fire Milk is hot going down, and even hotter when coming back up.\n
Rarity: Uncommon

Music to help simplify life and warm the heart.
Catch a Fish in Old New Henford's Lake
Travel to the countryside neighborhood of Old New Henford and catch a fish in the emerald green lake there!
To make a cross-stitch, buy a Cross-stitch Kit or place an individual Cross-stitch Hoop of any size in {0.SimFirstName}'s inventory. Then, use the kit or hoop to make a pattern of your choosing.
Once the Creature Keeper is given the necessary ingredients, they'll give {0.SimFirstName} a mash to eat.
It's time to find Crumplebottom and Deliver the promised plant to her.
Deliver an Aubergine to Agatha Crumplebottom
Deliver an Aubergine to Agnes Crumplebottom
Deliver a Blueberry to Agatha Crumplebottom
Deliver a Blueberry to Agnes Crumplebottom
Deliver Blueberry Jam to the Creature Keeper

First, {0.SimFirstName} will need some blueberries. They can be found on blueberry bushes growing around Henford-on-Bagley, cultivated in {M0.his}{F0.her} home garden, or they're occasionally sold at the garden shop located in Finchwick's square. Once acquired, {0.SimFirstName} can use Canning on a stove to turn Blueberries into Blueberry Jam. {M0.He}{F0.She} will need Level 2 Cooking Skill to be able to create Blueberry Jam. Finally, deliver the Blueberry Jam to the Creature Keeper.
Chickens fed a Fruity Treat will produce a Blue Egg. Check the Animal Treats section of {0.SimFirstName}'s notebook for information on how to make a Fruity Treat.
Deliver a Blue Egg to the Grocery Deliverer
Deliver a Blue Egg to the Grocery Owner
Llamas fed a Fruity Treat will produce Blue Llama Wool, which can then be sheared. Check the Animal Treats section of {0.SimFirstName}'s notebook for information on how to make a Fruity Treat.
Deliver Blue Llama Wool to the Grocery Deliverer
Deliver Blue Llama Wool to the Grocery Owner
Deliver 3 Chocoberries to the Creature Keeper
A chocoberry bush grows within the Bramblewood's island ruins, or can be cultivated in a home garden. Chocoberries are also occasionally on sale at the shops in Finchwick's square.
Give a Chocoberry to the Grocery Deliverer
The Grocery Deliverer mentioned wanting to make their own Chocolate Pie, so find another Chocoberry and give it to them.
Give a Chocolate Pie to the Grocery Deliverer

Using chocoberries, cook a Chocolate Pie and give it to the Grocery Deliverer. Chocoberry bushes grow near the island ruins in the Bramblewood, or can be cultivated in a home garden. Chocoberries are also occasionally on sale at the shops in Finchwick's square. {0.SimFirstName} will need Level 5 Cooking Skill to be able to cook a Chocolate Pie.
Deliver Chocolate Syrup to the Creature Keeper

First, {0.SimFirstName} will need some chocoberries. They can be found on chocoberry bushes growing around Henford-on-Bagley, cultivated in {M0.his}{F0.her} home garden, or they're occasionally sold at the garden shop located in Finchwick's square. Once acquired, {0.SimFirstName} can use Canning on a stove to turn chocoberries into Chocolate Syrup. {M0.He}{F0.She} will need Level 3 Cooking Skill to be able to create Chocolate Syrup. Finally, deliver the Chocolate Syrup to the Creature Keeper.
Deliver the Cross-stitch to the Mayor
Take the cross-stitch and deliver it to Henford-on-Bagley's Mayor as a gift, letting them know it's a gesture from the Grocery Deliverer.
Deliver a Cross-stitch to Agnes Crumplebottom

Buy a Cross-stitch Kit or place an individual Cross-stitch Hoop of any size in {0.SimFirstName}'s inventory. Then, use the kit or hoop to make a pattern of your choosing. Finally, deliver the cross-stitch to Agnes.
Deliver Another Cross-stitch to Agnes Crumplebottom
It seems like that first cross-stitch didn't satisfy Agnes, so {0.SimFirstName} needs to Deliver another.
Deliver a Dessert to Agatha Crumplebottom
After that sweet gossip, it's time to indulge Agatha's sweet tooth by making or buying a dessert and then delivering it to her.
Deliver a Dozen White Eggs to the Grocery Owner
White eggs can be obtained from hens in a Chicken Coop or purchased at the Grocery Shop in Finchwick's square.
Cows fed a Fruity Treat will produce Enriched Milk. Check the Animal Treats section of {0.SimFirstName}'s notebook for information on how to make a Fruity Treat.
Deliver a Bottle of Enriched Milk to the Grocery Deliverer
Deliver a Bottle of Enriched Milk to the Grocery Owner
Deliver Rose to the Creature Keeper

The Creature Keeper can often be found in the Bramblewood near their cottage or out and about tending to the various critters in that neighborhood. Find them, and give them the rose that the Grocery Owner asked you to send along.\n\nShould you happen to lose the rose the Grocery Owner provided and find yourself in need of another one, they're occasionally sold at the Garden Shop in Finchwick's square. Alternatively, there's always the old fashioned approach of simply growing a rose bush of your own at home.

Which came first - the golden chicken or the golden egg? Chickens who are both Very Happy, and have a great relationship with a Sim have a chance to lay a Golden Egg. So keep your chickens close and cooing, then Give Golden Egg to the villager Sim.
Give a Golden Egg to Agatha Crumplebottom
Give a Golden Egg to Agnes Crumplebottom
Give a Golden Egg to the Grocery Deliverer
Give a Golden Egg to the Grocer Owner
Give a Golden Egg to the Mayor

Deliver a Jar of Mayonnaise to Agnes Crumplebottom

Why does she want a jar of... maybe it's better not to ask. To make homemade mayonnaise, you'll need Level 3 Cooking Skill, and an Egg. Then, mayonnaise can be made by Canning eggs on a stove. Eggs can be acquired from a chicken coop, or purchased from the Grocery Shop located in Finchwick's square. If you're lucky, the Grocery Shop occasionally has Mayonnaise for sale as well, allowing you to bypass all the hard work!
Cows fed a Veggie Treat will produce Mighty Plant Milk. Check the Animal Treats section of {0.SimFirstName}'s notebook for information on how to make a Veggie Treat.
Deliver a Bottle of Mighty Plant Milk to the Grocery Deliverer
Deliver a Bottle of Mighty Plant Milk to the Grocery Owner
Deliver 6 Spicy Mushrooms to the Creature Keeper
These mushrooms can be foraged in the Bramblewood or cultivated in a home garden. They are also occasionally on sale at the grocery shop in Finchwick's square.
Deliver a Single Serving of Nightly Mushroom Soup to the Creature Keeper

Wait for the sun to set, then visit the Bramblewood and search the countryside for Nightly Mushrooms. Once acquired, use the mushrooms to cook a Single Serving of Nightly Mushroom Soup and Deliver it to the Creature Keeper.\n\n{0.SimFirstName} will need Level 4 Cooking Skill to be able to prepare Nightly Mushroom Soup.
Let the Midnight Treat you feed your cow match the darkness in your soul. Milk the midnight beast to release its angsty milk, then Give Obsidian Milk to the villager Sim.

Give Obsidian Milk to the Grocery Owner

Berries can be found on bushes around Henford-on-Bagley, or they can be cultivated in a home garden. They're also sometimes available at the grocery shop in Finchwick, or you can trade for them by visiting the Creature Keeper in the Bramblewood.
Chickens fed a Pumpkin Treat will lay an Orange Egg. Check the Animal Treats section of {0.SimFirstName}'s notebook for information on how to make a Pumpkin Treat.

Deliver an Orange Egg to the Grocery Owner

Deliver a Bottle of Pumpkin Spice Milk to the Grocery Deliverer

Deliver Rainbow Wool to Agatha Crumplebottom

Deliver Rainbow Wool to the Grocery Owner

First, {0.SimFirstName} will need some raspberries. They can be found on raspberry bushes growing around Henford-on-Bagley, cultivated in {M0.his}{F0.her} home garden, or they're occasionally sold at the garden shop located in Finchwick's square. Finally, deliver the Raspberry Jam to the Creature Keeper.
Deliver Single Serving of Food to the Grocery Owner
Cook or purchase any Single Serving of food and Deliver Single Serving of Food to the Grocery Owner.
Deliver a Full Pie to the Mystery Gifter
One final step: confront the mystery gifter and Deliver a Pie to them (a full pie of your choosing of course; a slice just won't do!) to give them a taste of their own kindness...in pie form.
Deliver the Village Package to the Grocery Deliverer
Package acquired! Now it's time to reunite it with its intended recipient.
Deliver the Village Package to the Mayor
Deliver the Village Package to the Pub Owner
Deliver a Charming Mushroom and a Verdant Mushroom to the Pub Owner
These mushrooms can be foraged in the Bramblewood or cultivated in a home garden. Get the required mushrooms and deliver them to the Pub Owner.
Deliver a Watermelon to Agatha Crumplebottom
Deliver a Watermelon to Agnes Crumplebottom
Deliver White Llama Wool to Agnes Crumplebottom
Sims can get White Llama Wool by shearing a white llama. Alternatively, white llama wool is occasionally sold at the Garden Shop that's located in Finchwick's square.
Bring Some Milk to Agnes Crumplebottom

She's thirsty! She wants some milk! After acquiring a bottle of milk, find Agnes and select Deliver Milk.\n\nOne surefire way of acquiring milk is to go to the source... Milk a cow, should you own one. Alternatively, bottles of fresh milk can be purchased from the Grocery Shop located in Finchwick's square.
Sing to Birds and Have Them Sing Along
Find a flock of birds in the Bramblewood or Old New Henford and Sing To them! If they like {0.SimFirstName} enough, they'll sing back.
Talk to a Flock of Birds While Mashed

There are a couple of hollowed out dead trees near the banks of the river in the Bramblewood with birds to talk to! Better do it before the effects of the mash wear off. If they do, you can ask the Creature Keeper for more Mushroom Mash.
Flocks of wild birds can be found nesting in hollowed out dead trees in the Bramblewood and Old New Henford neighborhoods.
Sing to {1.Number} Foxes and Have Them Howl Along

Find {1.Number} different Foxes and Sing To them. If the Fox likes {0.SimFirstName} and {M0.his}{F0.her} singing, they'll join in and howl along!\n\nFoxes often stick close to their den by the island ruins in the Bramblewood, but you'll also find them all around Henford-on-Bagley if you keep an eye out.

Wild foxes are sometimes seen in Old New Henford, but they're most commonly found in the Bramblewood. It's there that you'll frequently find them by their den, under the big tree that grows amidst the ruins.

Befriend some rabbits, then give them a hug! \n\nWild rabbits can be found living inside cut down tree stumps in the neighborhoods of the Bramblewood and Old New Henford, located in Henford-on-Bagley.
Wild rabbits can be found hopping around the Bramblewood and Old New Henford neighborhoods. Look for the tree stumps that they call home.
Browse the Garden or Grocery Shop in Finchwick
Travel to Finchwick and select Buy Garden Shop Items or Buy Grocery Shop Items from either of the two stalls located in the square to browse the wares on offer.

Plant, tend, and grow a blueberry bush in your home garden. Then, Harvest Blueberries from it once it's fully grown.\n\nTo find a blueberry to plant in your garden, search for mature blueberry bushes that grow around the world of Henford-on-Bagley and pluck a blueberry from them, or look for blueberries to occasionally be sold by both the Garden and Grocery Shops located in Finchwick's square.

Plant, tend, and grow a raspberry bush in your home garden. Then, Harvest Raspberries from it once it's fully grown.\n\nTo find a raspberry to plant in your garden, search for mature raspberry bushes that grow around the world of Henford-on-Bagley and pluck a raspberry from them, or look for raspberries to occasionally be sold by both the Garden and Grocery Shops located in Finchwick's square.

Oversized crops like aubergines can only be grown in garden patches. Purchase an In-Ground Garden Patch or the Mounded In-Ground Garden Patch to add to your home garden, and then use the patch to Purchase Oversized Crop Seeds and plant them. With some routine gardening care and patience, the Aubergine will be harvestable once it matures.

Oversized crops like lettuce can only be grown in garden patches. Purchase an In-Ground Garden Patch or the Mounded In-Ground Garden Patch to add to your home garden, and then use the patch to Purchase Oversized Crop Seeds and plant them. With some routine gardening care and patience, Lettuce will be harvestable once it matures.

Oversized crops like pumpkins can only be grown in garden patches. Purchase an In-Ground Garden Patch or the Mounded In-Ground Garden Patch to add to your home garden, and then use the patch to Purchase Oversized Crop Seeds and plant them. With some routine gardening care and patience, a Pumpkin will be harvestable once it matures.

Oversized crops like watermelons can only be grown in garden patches. Purchase an In-Ground Garden Patch or the Mounded In-Ground Garden Patch to add to your home garden, and then use the patch to Purchase Oversized Crop Seeds and plant them. With some routine gardening care and patience, a Watermelon will be harvestable once it matures.

Pumpkins can only be grown in garden patches. Purchase an In-Ground Garden Patch or the Mounded In-Ground Garden Patch and add it to your home garden, then use the Pumpkin Seeds that Agnes gave you to plant a pumpkin. \n\nShould you lose your pumpkin seeds, you can use the garden patch to Purchase Oversized Crop Seeds and acquire more.
Take a Photo Outside of Henford-on-Bagley
Travel somewhere outside Henford-on-Bagley and take a picture using {0.SimFirstName}'s phone or a camera.

It seems like a silly thing to do, but {0.SimFirstName} supposes {M0.he}{F0.she} should find a gnome to Talk To. Should {M0.he}{F0.she} fail in {M0.his}{F0.her} search, there are always gnomes to be purchased in Build Mode; they make fantastic additions to any home garden.

Find Agatha and Report on Single Sims to her so she can stay informed on all the potential meddling... (ahem; matchmaking!) she can do around the village.

Now that all the meddling and peddling is complete, find Agatha and Celebrate with her!
Encourage One Sim Who Received a Rose to Flirt With the Other Sim

Now that each Sim in this hopeful pairing has accepted a rose, they're eager to see what master matchmaker Agatha Crumplebottom has in store for them. Gather both of these Sims together, and chat with one of them to encourage them to to flirt with the other one.\n\nBoth Sims will need to be nearby, so make sure neither has wandered off!
Find two single Sims that would make a cute couple, gather them together, and Offer a Rose to each of them.

Sell a Watermelon To {1.Number} other Sims. Some Sims may need to warm up to the idea of buying one.\n\nIf you find yourself in need of more Watermelons to sell, they're easy to acquire. Oversized crops like watermelons can only be grown in garden patches. Purchase an In-Ground Garden Patch or the Mounded In-Ground Garden Patch to add to your home garden, and then use the patch to Purchase Oversized Crop Seeds and plant them. With some routine gardening care and patience, a Watermelon will be harvestable once it matures.
Sell {1.Number} Lettuce Seeds to Other Sims

Sell Lettuce Seeds To {1.Number} other Sims. Some Sims may need to warm up to the idea of buying some.\n\nIf you find yourself in need of more lettuce seeds to sell, they're easy to acquire. Purchase an In-Ground Garden Patch or the Mounded In-Ground Garden Patch to add to your home garden. Then, use the patch to Purchase Oversized Crop Seeds and you'll find lettuce seeds for sale.

Find some Sims around the village during the day who seem to be gossiping about other Sims. Then successfully Eavesdrop on Gossip or Ask for Juicy Gossip, depending on how well {0.SimFirstName} knows them.

Win a Competition at the Finchwick Fair

There's a fair every Saturday in Finchwick with competitions to be won. Check the board near the shops in Finchwick's square for information on the next fair, or open your calendar for a full schedule of competitions taking place at the fair in the near future. Prepare your best plants, animals, or pies and then head to the fair to take home the prize!
Purchase 1 Cow, Chicken, or Llama on Your Home Lot
Place an Animal Shed or Chicken Coop from Build Mode onto your lot. Then, click on either object to purchase a Cow, Llama, or Chicken.
Socialize with a Fox, Rabbit, or Bird 5 Times
In Henford-on-Bagley, click on a Flock of Wild Birds, Fox, or Rabbit to interact with them. Tip: If you're having trouble finding these creatures, try visiting the Bramblewood neighborhood.
Purchase 1 Garden Patch for Your Home Lot
Go into Build Mode and purchase a Garden Patch for your home lot. Place it down and enter Live Mode.
Visit Finchwick, Old New Henford, and the Bramblewood Neighborhoods in Henford-on-Bagley
Click on the Phone and select "Travel..." Then, visit each of the three neighborhoods in Henford-on-Bagley.
Befriend a Chicken, Cow, or Llama
Interact with a Chicken, Cow, or Llama by clicking on them. Prioritize positive social interactions to get them to like you.
Place 1 Wild Rabbit Home or Flock of Wild Birds on Your Home Lot
Unlock the Wild Rabbit Home or a Flock of Wild Birds by befriending these animals in the wild. Once you have unlocked either of them, visit Build Mode and place one on your home lot.
Reach Level 3 Gardening Skill. Then click on a plant and choose "Fertilize." Select an item to Fertilize the plant.
Give 3 Gifts to Foxes, Rabbits, or Birds
Locate a Rabbit, Fox, or Flock of Wild Birds and click on them to "Give Gift." Meet the Friendship and Item requirements indicated to give them a gift.

Click on any Refrigerator, Chicken Coop, or Animal Shed. Choose to "Create Animal Treats..." Choose which ingredients to use, and have your Sim create Animal Treats. Tip: Certain Animal Treat types will need to be learned before you can make them.

Purchase Oversized Crop seeds from your phone, computer, or at the Garden Shop in Finchwick's Village Square. Care for your oversized crops by using Fertilizer and tending to them. This will improve their quality throughout the growth cycle.
Travel to the Bramblewood neighborhood in Henford-on-Bagley. Locate a harvestable hidden in the woods and collect it.
Reach Maximum Relationship with a Cow, Chicken, or Llama

In Build Mode, purchase an Animal Shed or Chicken Coop. In Live Mode, click on the shed or coop to purchase an animal. Interact positively with the animal to befriend it. Continue to do this until the relationship is maxed out.
Receive 3 Gifts from Rabbits or Birds
Once you have a Wild Rabbit Home or a Flock of Wild Birds on your home lot, continue to interact with the creatures to befriend them. Eventually, they will bring you gifts.
Win a Competition in Henford-on-Bagley's Finchwick Fair

Travel to Henford-on-Bagley's Finchwick neighborhood and visit the village square to interact with the festival sign or open the Calendar to view upcoming Finchwick Fairs. See which fair type is scheduled for the week, then prepare by tending or creating the best applicable entry animal or item. When it is time for the Finchwick Fair to start, travel to Henford-on-Bagley's Finchwick neighborhood and attend the fair. Click on a competition stall or stand to submit your competition entry. Then, wait for the judge to review your submission and the fair to end. Tip: Happy animals, better quality items and animals, and rare variants of animals and items are more likely to win.

From the natural beauty of Cordelia Falls to the clear, brisk currents of the River Bagley, the mingling of earth and water makes Henford-on-Bagley a lovely place to visit but perhaps an even lovelier place to live. Villagers here connect with the history of the land while finding friendship in the the furry and feathery creatures that inhabit the woods. So what if the average neighbor is a little more gossipy? You couldn't ask for a better place to grow, tend, and nurture a more natural life.
