After the Great Sloth Invasion, Princess Cordelia was forced to flee her palace with few belongings and take refuge in the country. One of the first places she settled was Henford-on-Bagley. She spent lots of time enjoying the countryside, and a simpler way of life.
One such novel experience for her was the concept of going up and down stairs. In her palace, her family prided themselves on efficiency and so she always had a stair butler who carried her up and down stairs.
Since she had to fire all of her staff during the Great Sloth Invasion, unfortunately the stair butler could not join her in Henford-on-Bagley.
On the bright side, she experienced climbing this very set of stairs for the first time. She referred to them as "peasant stairs" and wrote about them in her diary. There's a first time for everything. And if you're in the market for a good stair-butler, hers is still looking for work.

{0.SimFirstName}'s proficiency with a needle has made them a crafting connoisseur. {0.SimFirstName} now has a pattern for Foxes, Chickens, and a Gnome. {F0.She}{M0.He} can also stitch some delicious foods! Nothing says love like cross-stitched cheese.

{0.SimFirstName} is now a stitching savant! No longer restricted to the confines of a pattern, {F0.she}{M0.he} can now Stitch by Reference! Watch {0.SimName} take a picture and masterfully stitch it into existence!

{0.SimFirstName} has their 14-count Aida cloth at the ready as {F0.she}{M0.he} embarks into the world of cross-stitch. {F0.She}{M0.He} can now stitch Rainbows, Shapes, and Stick Figures. We all have to start somewhere! Llama wool can be used to add that extra "home-made" feel.

{0.SimFirstName} is ready to take on some more advanced patterns! Now {F0.she}{M0.he} has patterns for inspirational or funny phrases that will put you in stitches! ...Maybe I should unpick that joke and try again.

14-count? Who is she? {0.SimFirstName} has backstitched {F0.her}{M0.his} way to the next level. {F0.She}{M0.He} can now stitch pumpkins, mushrooms, and berries! Who said you needed to go outside to enjoy the beauty of nature?

Nothing says love and patience like a carefully stitched piece of art! Cross-stitch pieces are perfect for decorations, selling, or as a gift for the little critter hanging around your garden. Choose from three different size hoops and get stitching! Just beware of resting stitch face!\n\nYour Sim can learn new patterns with each level up but maybe talking to a few folks in town will give {F0.her}{M0.his} some inspiration. Some of the small critters might even give {F0.her}{M0.his} something new to stitch, but only if you give them something nice in return!
These Sims are obsessed with animals, and will seek their company often. They will have an easier time caring for animals and getting closer to them.
These Sims will become sick if they eat dairy, but will feel great if they have avoided it for a while.

Nature Conversationalist Sims have improved relationships with animals, allowing their animals to live longer, happier lives. Rabbits and birds will bring them more gifts. And they can interact with plants in unique ways, receiving more yield from harvests. They will also receive free grocery delivery, and, when residing in Henford-on-Bagley, a discount on their bills.

Chickens make Eggs and some Eggs make Chickens! Which came first? The Chicken Coop! Purchase the Coop in Build Mode and then Sims can purchase Hens, Roosters, and Chicks from it.\n\nChickens sleep in the Coop at night. Sims can call them outside at any time.

Visit the Creature Keeper next to the Volpe Island ruins in The Bramblewood to purchase outfits. The stock rotates daily! If you bring Llama Wool, the Creature Keeper even can craft outfits from it.\n\nVillagers seeking help may offer outfits as rewards for completing Village Errands around Henford-on-Bagley.
Sims with an outfit in their Inventory can approach the matching species of animal and "Dress" them. Clothed animals can try on other outfits or the Sim can "Take Clothes" back.

Dressing up your animals in adorable outfits has no tangible benefits other than being heart-meltingly cute. Okay, maybe two benefits - it helps in telling animals apart. Outfits are available for Chickens, Cows, Foxes, Llamas, and Rabbits.

Foxes can be dealt with in other more direct ways though. Should a fox visit your lot with bad intentions, you can approach them and Shoo them away. If you're feeling proactive about protecting your Chicken Coop, Sims with the Handiness Skill can upgrade it with the "Fox Be-Gone Alarm".\n\nAnimals can also help ward off foxes. Roosters are natural foes to foxes; they'll aggressively pursue any fox in their proximity that approaches the Chicken Coop. Llamas are also fearless fox defenders. Llamas will spit at any fox in the nearby vicinity to scare them away.

Foxes roam the world of Henford-on-Bagley. Most often they keep their distance from residences, preferring to roam in secluded areas. In particular, they're commonly found near their fox den, located in the shade of the great tree at the Volpe Island ruins in the Bramblewood. However, if left unchecked, foxes can pose a threat to your garden, your chickens, your eggs, and any rabbits that are around. While a locked door poses no challenge to a sly fox, there are other ways to deal with them...

As a player, you also have control over if you want to foxes to visit your lot. The "Wild Foxes" Lot Challenge can be applied to, or removed from, any lot within Build Mode. Lots that have this challenge applied (all lots in Henford-on-Bagley have this challenge by default), will have foxes occasionally visit the lot to steal from your garden, or attack your animals. You can also enable the Wild Foxes Lot Challenge in other worlds, so as to experience foxes in any location.

A friendly way to neutralize any danger from the local fox population is simply by befriending them. Foxes love receiving gifts, but they're also generally happy just to socialize with any Sim who shows interest in spending time with them. They can be a bit mischievous at first, but they'll come around as you gain their trust. Once you're friends with a fox, you can approach them and "Ask Not to Steal". From that point on, as long as you maintain a friendly relationship with them, they'll willingly leave your garden and your critters alone.

Everyone knows the best thing about gifts... It's receiving them! Happily, Birds and Rabbits have gifts they want to share with those they befriend. When you see these animals thinking about a gift box, you'll know they have a gift they want to share. Select "Take Gift" from the animal. As the Sim's relationship with an animal improves, the gifts will only get better!

Each wild animal has their own preferences for gifts they dislike, like, and love. Sometimes Sims can try "Discover Gift Preferences" and the animal will share how they feel about a type of gift. More often, though, Sims need to offer a gift and note how the animal reacts. As Sims learn which types the animal likes, the question mark next to each type of gift becomes a thumbs up, thumbs down, or a heart so Sims know which to continue giving and which to avoid.

Gift giving is a great way to build friendship with Birds, Foxes, and Rabbits. Cooking food and then giving it to a wild animal is one of the easiest types, but there are many more options. When attempting to "Give Gift", you'll see a variety of gifts Sims can offer to gain their trust.

Once you've located a Wild Rabbit, you can approach it and begin interacting with it. You can start slowly - choosing to observe them from a distance, or if you're feeling bold you may approach them and interact with them directly. See the Gifts for Wild Animals lesson for tips on how to quickly build a friendship with the various rabbits you'll encounter in Henford-on-Bagley!

Rabbits are curious little critters who can be found hopping around in both Old New Henford and The Bramblewood. Should you live in those neighborhoods, don't be surprised to find cute bunnies burrowing their way into your yard to pay a visit. If you're looking for a rabbit in the wild though, try locating the stumps of cut down trees that they call home near the banks of the River Bagley. When traveling within Henford-on-Bagley, you'll even find these tree stumps dotted on the map, to help you locate them within the world.

...Oh, you're still reading? By now, you're probably thinking rabbits are all fluff and fun. But you'd be wrong. Do not... I repeat, DO NOT get on a rabbit's bad side. The consequences can be disastrous. You've been warned...\n\nPsst... Locking your doors won't save you. Rabbits can burrow right under them.

Building a friendship with a rabbit has its advantages. Not only are they fun for Sims of nearly every age, but rabbits are wonderful at helping tend to nearby gardens. If you live in Old New Henford or The Bramblewood, you can ask rabbits living in the neighborhood to help with gardening, and you'll find they'll nibble on any weeds that pop up to allow your plants to grow healthy and strong! In addition, rabbits find Garden Patches to be tantalizing toilets... Their little pellets of poop will naturally fertilize the Oversized Crops in your garden, helping them to grow nice and large!

Even if you're not a local, befriending the rabbits in Henford-on-Bagley has clear benefits. Once you're friends with any Wild Rabbit, you can purchase a rabbit home for your own home with all of the gardening benefits they can bestow. Find it in the Build Mode catalog by searching for "Wild Rabbit Home". Soon you will have rabbits darting across your lawn!

Building a friendship with a Flock of Wild Birds has its advantages. Not only will you have a flock of feathered friends, but birds are quite adept at assisting with nearby gardens. Should you call Old New Henford or The Bramblewood your Sims' home, you can ask the local flock to help with gardening, and you'll find they'll keep your garden free of pesky insects. They'll also sing their lilting bird song to your Oversized Crops, helping them grow faster and even larger!

Once you've located a Flock of Wild Birds, you can approach their home and begin interacting with them. You can start slowly - choosing to observe them from a distance, or if you're feeling bold you may approach them and interact with them directly. Should they enjoy your banter, you'll find yourself building a friendship with the entire flock that calls the tree trunk their home.

Even if you're not a local, befriending the birds in Henford-on-Bagley has clear benefits. Once you're friends with one of the flocks, you can purchase a bird home for your own home along with all of the gardening benefits they can bestow. Find it in the Build Mode catalog by searching for "Flock of Wild Birds". Soon you will have birds flitting to-and-fro outside your windows!

Flocks of Wild Birds can be found in the countryside of both Old New Henford and The Bramblewood. They live within rotting tree trunks on the shores of the River Bagley. When traveling within Henford-on-Bagley, you'll even find these tree trunks dotted on the map, to help you locate them within the world.

There are a few shortcuts to travel to Finchwick’s village square for a fair that has started:
  1. Click the notification at the top of the screen and select the option to travel
  2. Open the Calendar, select the Finchwick Fair, and press the button at the bottom of the flyer.
  3. Open the flyer from the Henford-on-Bagley Community Information Sign in Old New Henford's community garden

Each week, Henford-on-Bagley’s Finchwick neighborhood hosts a different festival in the village square. Listen to music, win ribbons and other prizes, and purchase unique items from the Garden and Grocery Shops in Finchwick’s square. Be sure to check out all five festivals!
  • Finchwick Chicken Fair
  • Finchwick Cow Fair
  • Finchwick Llama Fair
  • Finchwick Oversized Crop Fair
  • Finchwick Garden Fair

Each fair also hosts two different competitions. Learn about upcoming fair competitions to prepare your entries! 

Open the Calendar from the bottom of the screen and then highlight the relevant event to see which competitions are coming up. 

The Fair Flyer also is posted on each Henford-on-Bagley Community Information Sign. A sign is located in Finchwick’s village square and another is in Old New Henford’s community garden.

Each Finchwick Fair hosts two competitions. Be sure to bring your entries in your Sim’s Inventory! To add an item to the Inventory, click on the item and choose “Add to Inventory.” Sims with valid competition items can submit their entries at a competition stand or stall. Items are judged on quality, rarity, and, when applicable, size, cleanliness, and happiness. \n\nCompetitions:
  • Finchwick Chicken Fair: Chickens and Eggs
  • Finchwick Cow Fair: Cows and Milk
  • Finchwick Llama Fair: Llamas and Wool
  • Finchwick Oversized Crop Fair: Oversized Crops and Pies
  • Finchwick Garden Fair: Fruits, Vegetables, Flowers, or Herbs and Pies

As you complete errands for the different villagers, individual villagers will begin to entrust you with more challenging errands that offer a wider range of rewards. Continue to visit them daily to see what errands they need help with.

Certain villagers living in Henford-on-Bagley have errands that they'd appreciate your help with. These are Sims that have special roles within the village, such as the Mayor, the Pub Owner, and many others. The best way to get acquainted with these Sims is by visiting the Information Board in Finchwick's square. There, you'll find the names of these villagers, their roles, and what they look like.

Once you've located one of these special villagers, you can interact with them and "Offer Help With Errands". They'll be happy to let you know various tasks that they currently need assistance with. You can select up to three errands to work on simultaneously, and there's no time limit to complete them. Different errands from different villagers will provide different rewards, so be sure to meet everyone in the town to see what they're offering.

After you've started an errand, you'll find information on what tasks you must complete within your Sim's Career Panel. As tasks are completed, new tasks may appear. Once all tasks are checked off, you'll receive your rewards! If you're ever feeling stuck and don't know how to complete a task, hover your cursor over the task to see a tooltip with more explicit information on what must be done to progress.

The Villagers' special title displays above their name when you hover over them. You also can "Learn about Villagers" from a Henford-on-Bagley Community Information Sign to see who's who. Finchwick's village square and Old New Henford’s community garden both have this sign.

Henford-on-Bagley is a close-knit community run by a handful of Sims with distinct roles. These include:
  • Garden Shop Owner
  • Grocery Shop Owner
  • Creature Keeper
  • Grocery Deliverer
  • Mayor of Finchwick
  • Pub Owner

But where can you find these Sims? Most of them often are in or around Finchwick’s village square in Henford-on-Bagley. The Pub Owner tends the local Bar. The Creature Keeper roams the Bramblewood, caring for the wild animals. Select the Creature Keeper’s house nestled across from the Isle of Volpe ruins to see his or her whereabouts.

Sims can give these locals a special gift called a Finchwick Favor once a day, a local tradition! Having a “Henford Heart-to-Heart” conversation with them might reveal what they would like. Then again, they might say something else unexpected, especially if they really like the Sim! While chatting with them, see if they could use a hand with anything with “Offer to Help with Errands…”. They are sure to reward helpful Sims.

Just like Sims, animals need to eat. Chickens: Feed Chickens by selecting the Chicken itself or selecting the Chicken Coop to scatter feed for multiple chickens. Cows and Llamas: The Animal Shed has a feed trough that Sims should keep stocked. The animals will eat on their own when food is available there. Sims also can feed them by hand. Don't worry about overfeeding - they'll never get too full.

Animals that are Unhappy for too long eventually leave. Don't worry - A warning will appear well before this happens. To keep animals happy at home, just care for their needs by feeding, cleaning, and socializing.

Animals don't like being dirty - who does? (Okay, besides Slob Sims....) Chickens: When left unattended, Chicken Coops get dirty. Sims can't clean chickens directly. Chickens preen themselves clean whenever they need to and are able. Sims can help keep their chickens clean by keeping the Chicken Coop clean. Cows and Llamas: Just like Coops, Animal Sheds and their occupants get dirty over time. Sims can brush Cows and Llamas to clean them and have a nice moment together. Sims should clean out Animal Sheds every day or two.

An animal's desire for attention is shown by the Attention need.

Sims can socialize with animals in a variety of ways. The chance of that going well is better when the Sim is in a good mood and the animal is Happy. Nearby animals gain some Attention, too, when those actions go well.

If socializing is not going well, hover over the animal to check for unmet needs that might be making the animal grouchy. (But if the animal hates a Sim that has been mean to them repeatedly, don't come crying to us.)

To keep Grim permanently away from animals, go to "Game Options" then choose "Pack Settings." Find the "Cottage Living" section and uncheck "Animal Aging." Note: This applies to wild animals as well, so Foxes and Rabbits also will not pass away.

Chickens, Cows, and Llamas rely on Sims to take care of them and attend to their needs: Hygiene, Attention, and Hunger. All animals initially feel Fine. When all their needs are fulfilled, they become Happy!\n\nHover over an animal to see its Happiness level, status of needs, and other information such as life stage.

For better or worse, animals age just like Sims. Grim will come to collect animal that has reached the end of its life.\n\nHappier animals tend to live longer, but happiness isn't the only factor that affects animal aging. Look for other ways to prolong the life of animals in your Sims' care!

Having happy animals is more than a reason to be proud: happier animals produce higher quality ingredients and respond more positively when Sims interact with them! The opposite holds true for Unhappy animals.\n\nAnimals that stay Happy long enough will become Very Happy. If any of the animal's needs fall too low, it will need time to become Very Happy once again. Don't worry if this happens! Keep caring for your animals and they'll be Very Happy before you know it.

Hens lay eggs roughly twice a day. Sims can collect eggs directly from the Chicken Coop at any time, but morning is best. Eggs can be sold, used as ingredients, and used to make certain Animal Treats. Chickens breed on their own as long as these conditions are met:
  • At least one Rooster and one Hen live in the Chicken Coop
  • The Chicken Coop has room for more Chickens
Once bred, a Hen has a chance of laying eggs that might hatch into Chicks!

When a Sim collects eggs, check their Inventory to see if any of the eggs are fertilized!

Drag or have the Sim place a hatchable egg in any available nest in a Chicken Coop. Up to three eggs can incubate in one coop and Hens returning to the coop will try to nest on them. These eggs eventually hatch no matter what, but they having a nesting Hen will help them hatch sooner and produce a happier Chick.

Watch for a notification when an egg is close to hatching. Sims can help the Chick hatch and enjoy the magical moment of new life entering the world.

Sims can try milking their Cows in early morning and around midday. Milking doesn't require any skill, but sometimes Cows have other ideas. Success is more likely when the Sim is in a good mood and the Cow's needs are met. Cows always produce regular Milk and provide additional special types of milk when fed certain Animal Treats. (See "Animal Treats" for more on producing special Milks.)\n\nMilk can be consumed directly (lactose-intolerant Sims beware!), sold, and used in recipes. Special Milks confer various benefits. Check the Notebook to learn more.

Once per day, starting early morning, Sims can trying shearing their Llamas and collect the Llama Wool. Shearing doesn't require any skill, but Llamas are not famous for being nice. Increase chance of success by ensuring the Sim is in a good mood, and that the Llama's needs are all taken care of. Shearing produces Llama Wool that matches the Llama's current color, and will turn the Llama back to its natural color. (See "Animal Treats" for notes on changing Llama color.)

Llama Wool can be sold, but has other uses, too. Use Llama Wool to reduce the cost of Cross-stitching or Knitting, or as a required ingredient in Animal Clothing. (The Creature Keeper can help!)

Shearing is optional: Sims cannot shear too much at a time, and unsheared Llamas don't experience any negative effects. (See "Animal Care" for notes on what is required care for animals.)

Cows and Llamas are adorable animal friends that can produce Milk and Wool to help Sims experience a full cottage lifestyle.

Purchasing and placing an Animal Shed will allow Sims to purchase either a Cow or Llama. Only one animal can be in a shed at a time.

Cows and Llamas can be called in or out of their shed. Animals will enter the shed at night to sleep.

Learn recipes for Animal Treats by feeding treats to animals or by learning them straight from treats in a Sim’s inventory.

Make Animal Treats from the fridge or from the animal’s home. Making treats requires the Sim to know the recipe and have the ingredients.

Check the Notebook to learn more about what each treat does.

Chickens, Cows, and Llamas love Animal Treats! Treats can help with animal care and provide cosmetic benefits. Sims can acquire them from the village shops, Finchwick Fair competitions, and Errands. Birds and Rabbits can bring treats as gifts!

Feeding certain treats to animals can have special results. 

Some treats change the color of a Llama's Wool. Shearing the Llama restores their original color.

Some treats enable Chickens to lay different types of Eggs. Some can be used in recipes and some may even hatch special Chickens.

Some treats result in different types of milk from Cows. These can be used in certain recipes and some have particular short-term effects on the Sims who drink them. That Fire Milk is spicy!

Lastly, some treats have the same effect on Chickens, Cows, and Llamas. For example, the Friendly Treat improves a Sim’s relationship with any of these animals.

Keep an eye out for wild animals such as rabbits and wild bird flocks. They live in The Bramblewood in Henford-on-Bagley. Befriending these animals provides Sims with companionship and they are great helpers in the garden.

For quick and easy ingredients, place a Grocery Delivery order from the phone or refrigerator. If you prefer a more "home grown" approach, place an Animal Shed and a Chicken Coop from Build Mode. This will enable you to purchase your very own Cows, Llamas, Roosters, and Hens. You even can raise baby Chicks!\n\nYou can also purchase a new Garden Patch from Build Mode and plant Giant Crops such as pumpkins, watermelon, and even aubergine if you are looking for a sustainable meat substitute in cooking.
Cottage life also is about taking time to "smell the roses". Be sure to enjoy the sights of Henford-on-Bagley, offer help to the local villagers, or just sit back and cross-stitch the night away.

Living off the land is a big part of the Cottage Living experience. Start by applying the Simple Living Lot Challenge in Build Mode. This requires Sims to cook with ingredients and results in higher quality meals.
Sims can shop for groceries at Goldbloom's Grocery Shop in Finchwick. They also can always order groceries via the phone or fridge.

Sims who master the Cooking skill on a lot with the Simple Living Lot Challenge will gain the ability to write a special cookbook! Sims who already have mastered the skill will gain this ability after cooking fifteen meals. This cookbook enables other Sims to master Cooking quickly by reading the book.
Get ingredients by gardening, caring for Chickens and Cows, visiting Goldbloom's Grocery Shop in Finchwick, or ordering groceries on the phone or fridge.
Simple Living is a Lot Challenge that requires your Sims to have ingredients to make meals.

The natural beauty of these woods have long provided a picturesque place for many wild birds, rabbits, and foxes to call home. Whether secreting a small surprise under Sophie the Snail, bringing an easel to paint the serene Cordelia Falls, foraging for wild mushrooms, or finding romance among the ruins on the Isle of Volpe, any Sim would be transformed by a day in the Bramblewood.

An area that boasts rolling hills, lush estates, and a small community garden, Old New Henford is perhaps best known for its historical naming woes. Initially known as Little Henford, the neighborhood renamed itself New Henford in an attempt to escape its diminutive origins. However, in neglecting to inform national mapmakers, they ceased to officially exist for a two-week period. When told that to be reinstated would require yet another name change, residents chose Old New Henford, which beat out the other choice - New New Henford - by a single vote.

Nestled along the River Bagley, the old mill village of Finchwick prides itself on its bustling and close-knit community. Its historic square features a pub and quaint stalls amid a flowering garden, perfect for a little window shopping. Tourists and locals alike flock to the weekly village fair, where Finchwick's Mayor makes a special appearance to judge entries and gossip about the latest happenings.
